﻿The [Napoleon of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill _ By _ [GILBERT]3-gilbert K. [CHESTERTON]4-chesterton _ TO HILAIRE BELLOC]1-napoleon of notting hill _ by _ gilbert k. chesterton _ to hilaire belloc _

_ For [every tiny town]346-every tiny town or place [God]199-god made the stars especially ; [Babies]200-babies look up with owlish face And see [them]200-babies tangled in a tree : [You]347-you saw a moon from [Sussex Downs]5-sussex downs , A [Sussex]6-sussex moon , untravelled still , [I]0-i saw a moon that was [the town]348-the town 's , The largest lamp on [Campden Hill]164-campden hill . _

_ Yea ; [Heaven]349-heaven is everywhere at [home]350-home The big blue cap that always fits , And so it is ( be calm ; [they]351-they come To goal at last , [my]0-i wandering wits ) , So is it with the heroic thing ; This shall not end for [the world]352-the world 's end , And though the sullen engines swing , Be [you]347-you not much afraid , [[my]0-i friend]353-my friend . _

_ This did not end by [Nelson]201-nelson 's urn Where an immortal [England]8-england sits-- Nor where [[your]347-you tall young men]354-your tall young men in turn Drank death like wine at [Austerlitz]9-austerlitz . And when the pedants bade [us]355-us mark What cold mechanic happenings Must come ; [our]355-us souls said in the dark , " Belike ; but there are likelier things . "[355-us] _

_ Likelier across [these flats]356-these flats afar These sulky levels smooth and free The drums shall crash a waltz of war And Death shall dance with Liberty ; Likelier the barricades shall blare Slaughter below and smoke above , And death and hate and hell declare That [men]357-men have found a thing to love . _

_ Far from [[your]347-you sunny uplands]358-your sunny uplands set [I]0-i saw the dream ; [the streets]359-the streets [I]0-i trod [The lit straight streets]360-the lit straight streets shot out and met [The starry streets]361-the starry streets that point to [God]199-god . This legend of an epic hour [A child]362-a child [I]0-i dreamed , and dream it still , Under [the great grey water - tower That strikes the stars on [Campden Hill]164-campden hill]363-the great grey water - tower that strikes the stars on campden hill . _

G. K. C. BOOK [I]0-i

_ [THE NAPOLEON OF NOTTING HILL]364-the napoleon of notting hill _

CHAPTER I--_Introductory Remarks on the Art of Prophecy _

[The human race]365-the human race , to which so many of [[my]0-i readers]366-my readers belong , has been playing at [children]367-children 's games from the beginning , and will probably do it till the end , which is a nuisance for [the few people who grow up]368-the few people who grow up . And one of the games to which it is most attached is called " Keep to - morrow dark , "[0-i] and which is also named ( by [the rustics in [Shropshire]10-shropshire]369-the rustics in shropshire , [I]0-i have no doubt ) " [Cheat the Prophet]1723-cheat the prophet . "[370-the players] [The players]370-the players listen very carefully and respectfully to all that [the clever men]371-the clever men have to say about what is to happen in the next generation . [The players]370-the players then wait until [all the clever men]373-all the clever men are dead , and bury [them]373-all the clever men nicely . [They]370-the players then go and do something else . That is all . For [a race of simple tastes]374-a race of simple tastes , however , it is great fun .

For [human beings]375-human beings , being [children]367-children , have the childish wilfulness and the childish secrecy . And [they]375-human beings never have from the beginning of [the world]352-the world done what [the wise men]378-the wise men have seen to be inevitable . [They]375-human beings stoned [the false prophets]379-the false prophets , it is said ; but [they]375-human beings could have stoned [true prophets]380-true prophets with a greater and juster enjoyment . Individually , [men]357-men may present a more or less rational appearance , eating , sleeping , and scheming . But humanity as a whole is changeful , mystical , fickle , delightful . [Men]357-men are [men]357-men , but [Man]384-man is [a woman]385-a woman .

But in the beginning of the twentieth century the game of Cheat [the Prophet]386-the prophet was made far more difficult than it had ever been before . The reason was , that there were [so many prophets]387-so many prophets and so many prophecies , that it was difficult to elude all [their]387-so many prophets ingenuities . When [a man]388-a man did something free and frantic and entirely [his]388-a man own , a horrible thought struck [him]388-a man afterwards ; it might have been predicted . Whenever [a duke]389-a duke climbed a lamp - post , when [a dean]390-a dean got drunk , [he]390-a dean could not be really happy , [he]390-a dean could not be certain that [he]390-a dean was not fulfilling some prophecy . In the beginning of the twentieth century [you]391-you could not see the ground for [clever men]392-clever men . [They]375-human beings were so common that [a stupid man]393-a stupid man was quite exceptional , and when [they]375-human beings found [him]393-a stupid man , [they]375-human beings followed [him]393-a stupid man in crowds down [the street]394-the street and treasured [him]393-a stupid man up and gave [him]393-a stupid man some high post in [the State]395-the state . And all [these clever men]396-these clever men were at work giving accounts of what would happen in the next age , all quite clear , all quite keen - sighted and ruthless , and all quite different . And it seemed that the good old game of hoodwinking [[your]391-you ancestors]397-your ancestors could not really be managed this time , because [the ancestors]398-the ancestors neglected meat and sleep and practical politics , so that [they]398-the ancestors might meditate day and night on what [[their]398-the ancestors descendants]399-their descendants would be likely to do .

But the way [the prophets of the twentieth century]400-the prophets of the twentieth century went to work was this . [They]400-the prophets of the twentieth century took something or other that was certainly going on in [their]400-the prophets of the twentieth century time , and then said that it would go on more and more until something extraordinary happened . And very often [they]400-the prophets of the twentieth century added that in some odd place that extraordinary thing had happened , and that it showed the signs of the times .

Thus , for instance , there were [Mr. H. G. Wells]202-mr. h. g. wells and [others , who thought that science would take charge of the future]401-others , who thought that science would take charge of the future ; and just as [the motor - car]402-the motor - car was quicker than [the coach]403-the coach , so some lovely thing would be quicker than [the motor - car]402-the motor - car ; and so on for ever . And there arose from [their]396-these clever men ashes [Dr. Quilp]203-dr. quilp , who said that [a man]388-a man could be sent on [his]388-a man machine so fast round [the world]352-the world that [he]388-a man could keep up a long , chatty conversation in [some old - world village]407-some old - world village by saying a word of a sentence each time [he]388-a man came round . And it was said that the experiment had been tried on [an apoplectic old major]408-an apoplectic old major , who was sent round [the world]352-the world so fast that there seemed to be ( to the inhabitants of some other star ) a continuous band round the earth of white whiskers , red complexion and tweeds -- a thing like the ring of Saturn .

Then there was [the opposite school]410-the opposite school . There was [Mr. Edward Carpenter]204-mr. edward carpenter , who thought [we]411-we should in a very short time return to Nature , and live simply and slowly as the animals do . And [Edward Carpenter]204-mr. edward carpenter was followed by [James Pickie]205-james pickie , D.D. ( of [Pocohontas College]11-pocohontas college ) , who said that [men]357-men were immensely improved by grazing , or taking [their]357-men food slowly and continuously , after the manner of cows . And [he]205-james pickie said that [he]205-james pickie had , with the most encouraging results , turned [city men]413-city men out on all fours in a field covered with veal cutlets . Then [Tolstoy]206-tolstoy and [the Humanitarians]414-the humanitarians said that [the world]352-the world was growing more merciful , and therefore [no one]416-no one would ever desire to kill . And [Mr. Mick]207-mr. mick not only became a vegetarian , but at length declared vegetarianism doomed ( " shedding , "[207-mr. mick] as [he]207-mr. mick called it finely , " the green blood of the silent animals "[207-mr. mick] ) , and predicted that [men in a better age]417-men in a better age would live on nothing but salt . And then came the pamphlet from [Oregon]12-oregon ( where the thing was tried ) , the pamphlet called " Why should [Salt]208-salt suffer ? "[207-mr. mick] and there was more trouble .

[ Illustration : [CITY MEN OUT ON ALL FOURS IN A FIELD COVERED WITH VEAL CUTLETS]209-city men out on all fours in a field covered with veal cutlets . ]

And on the other hand , [some people]418-some people were predicting that the lines of kinship would become narrower and sterner . There was [Mr. Cecil Rhodes]210-mr. cecil rhodes , who thought that the one thing of the future was [the British Empire]13-the british empire , and that there would be a gulf between those who were of [the Empire]419-the empire and [those who were not]420-those who were not , between [the Chinaman in [Hong Kong]14-hong kong]421-the chinaman in hong kong and [the Chinaman outside]422-the chinaman outside , between the Spaniard on [the Rock of [Gibraltar]15-gibraltar]423-the rock of gibraltar and [the Spaniard]424-the spaniard off [it]423-the rock of gibraltar , similar to the gulf between [man]384-man and the lower animals . And in the same way [[his]207-mr. mick impetuous friend]426-his impetuous friend , [Dr. Zoppi]211-dr. zoppi ( " the Paul of [Anglo - Saxonism]1724-anglo - saxonism "[211-dr. zoppi] ) , carried it yet further , and held that , as a result of this view , cannibalism should be held to mean eating [a member of the Empire]427-a member of the empire , not eating one of [the subject peoples]428-the subject peoples , who should , [he]207-mr. mick said , be killed without needless pain . [His]207-mr. mick horror at the idea of eating [a man in [British Guiana]16-british guiana]429-a man in british guiana showed how [they]430-they misunderstood [his]207-mr. mick stoicism who thought [him]207-mr. mick devoid of feeling . [He]207-mr. mick was , however , in a hard position ; as it was said that [he]207-mr. mick had attempted the experiment , and , living in [London]17-london , had to subsist entirely on [Italian organ - grinders]431-italian organ - grinders . And [his]207-mr. mick end was terrible , for just when [he]207-mr. mick had begun , [Sir Paul Swiller]212-sir paul swiller read [his]207-mr. mick great paper at the Royal Society , proving that [the savages]432-the savages were not only quite right in eating [[their]432-the savages enemies]433-their enemies , but right on moral and hygienic grounds , since it was true that the qualities of [the enemy]434-the enemy , when eaten , passed into the eater . The notion that the nature of [an Italian organ - man]435-an italian organ - man was irrevocably growing and burgeoning inside [him]207-mr. mick was almost more than [the kindly old professor]436-the kindly old professor could bear .

There was [Mr. Benjamin Kidd]213-mr. benjamin kidd , who said that the growing note of [[our]437-our race]438-our race would be the care for and knowledge of the future . [His]213-mr. benjamin kidd idea was developed more powerfully by [William Borker]214-william borker , who wrote that passage which [every schoolboy]439-every schoolboy knows by heart , about [men in future ages]440-men in future ages weeping by the graves of [[their]440-men in future ages descendants]399-their descendants , and [tourists]442-tourists being shown over the scene of the historic battle which was to take place some centuries afterwards .

And [Mr. Stead]215-mr. stead , too , was prominent , who thought that [England]8-england would in the twentieth century be united to [America]18-america ; and [[his]215-mr. stead young lieutenant]443-his young lieutenant , [Graham Podge]216-graham podge , who included [the states of [France]19-france]444-the states of france , [Germany]20-germany , and [Russia]21-russia in [the American Union]445-the american union , [the State of [Russia]21-russia]446-the state of russia being abbreviated to [Ra]217-ra .

There was [Mr. Sidney Webb]218-mr. sidney webb , also , who said that the future would see a continuously increasing order and neatness in the life of [the people]447-the people , and [[his]218-mr. sidney webb poor friend]448-his poor friend Fipps , who went mad and ran about [the country]449-the country with an axe , hacking branches off the trees whenever there were not the same number on both sides .

[All these clever men]450-all these clever men were prophesying with every variety of ingenuity what would happen soon , and [they]450-all these clever men all did it in the same way , by taking something [they]450-all these clever men saw " going strong , "[450-all these clever men] as the saying is , and carrying it as far as ever [their]450-all these clever men imagination could stretch . This , [they]450-all these clever men said , was the true and simple way of anticipating the future . " Just as , "[219-dr. pellkins] said [Dr. Pellkins]219-dr. pellkins , in a fine passage,--"just as when [we]1725-we see a pig in a litter larger than the other pigs , [we]1725-we know that by an unalterable law of the Inscrutable it will some day be larger than an elephant,--just as [we]1725-we know , when [we]1725-we see weeds and dandelions growing more and more thickly in [a garden]1726-a garden , that [they]450-all these clever men must , in spite of all [our]1725-we efforts , grow taller than the chimney - pots and swallow [the house]1727-the house from sight , so [we]1725-we know and reverently acknowledge , that when any power in human politics has shown for any period of time any considerable activity , it will go on until it reaches to the sky . "[219-dr. pellkins]

And it did certainly appear that [the prophets]451-the prophets had put [the people]447-the people ( engaged in the old game of [Cheat the Prophet]220-cheat the prophet ) in a quite unprecedented difficulty . It seemed really hard to do anything without fulfilling some of [their]447-the people prophecies .

But there was , nevertheless , in the eyes of [[labourers]453-labourers in [the streets]359-the streets]454-labourers in the streets , of [[peasants]456-peasants in [the fields]458-the fields]457-peasants in the fields , of [sailors]459-sailors and [children]367-children , and especially [women]461-women , a strange look that kept [the wise men]378-the wise men in a perfect fever of doubt . [They]378-the wise men could not fathom the motionless mirth in [their]378-the wise men eyes . [They]378-the wise men still had something up [their]378-the wise men sleeve ; [they]378-the wise men were still playing the game of [Cheat the Prophet]1723-cheat the prophet .

Then [the wise men]378-the wise men grew like wild things , and swayed hither and thither , crying , " What can it be ? What can it be ? What will [London]17-london be like a century hence ? Is there anything [we]1728-we have not thought of ? [Houses]1729-houses upside down -- more hygienic , perhaps ? [Men walking on hands]1730-men walking on hands -- make feet flexible , do n't [you]1731-you know ? Moon ... [motor - cars]1732-motor - cars ... no heads .... "[378-the wise men] And so [they]378-the wise men swayed and wondered until [they]378-the wise men died and were buried nicely .

Then [the people]447-the people went and did what [they]447-the people liked . Let [me]0-i no longer conceal the painful truth . [The people]447-the people had cheated [the prophets of the twentieth century]400-the prophets of the twentieth century . When the curtain goes up on this story , eighty years after the present date , [London]17-london is almost exactly like what [it]17-london is now .

CHAPTER II--_The Man in Green _

Very few words are needed to explain why [London]17-london , a hundred years hence , will be very like it is now , or rather , since [I]0-i must slip into a prophetic past , why [London]17-london , when [my]0-i story opens , was very like it was in those enviable days when [I]0-i was still alive .

The reason can be stated in one sentence . [The people]447-the people had absolutely lost faith in revolutions . All revolutions are doctrinal -- such as the French one , or the one that introduced Christianity . For it stands to common sense that [you]469-you can not upset all existing things , customs , and compromises , unless [you]469-you believe in something outside them , something positive and divine . Now , [England]8-england , during this century , lost all belief in this . [It]8-england believed in a thing called Evolution . And it said , " All theoretic changes have ended in blood and ennui . If [we]1733-we change , [we]1733-we must change slowly and safely , as the animals do . [Nature]221-nature 's revolutions are the only successful ones . There has been no conservative reaction in favour of tails . "[8-england]

And some things did change . Things that were not much thought of dropped out of sight . Things that had not often happened did not happen at all . Thus , for instance , [the actual physical force ruling [the country]449-the country]470-the actual physical force ruling the country , [the soldiers]472-the soldiers and [police]473-police , grew smaller and smaller , and at last vanished almost to a point . [The people]447-the people combined could have swept [the few policemen]475-the few policemen away in ten minutes : [they]447-the people did not , because [they]447-the people did not believe it would do [them]447-the people the least good . [They]447-the people had lost faith in revolutions .

Democracy was dead ; for [no one]416-no one minded [the governing class]477-the governing class governing . [England]8-england was now practically [a despotism]478-a despotism , but not an hereditary one . [Some one in the official class]479-some one in the official class was made [King]480-king . [No one]416-no one cared how : [no one]416-no one cared who . [He]479-some one in the official class was merely [an universal secretary]483-an universal secretary .

In this manner it happened that everything in [London]17-london was very quiet . That vague and somewhat depressed reliance upon things happening as they have always happened , which is with all [Londoners]22-londoners a mood , had become an assumed condition . There was really no reason for [any man]484-any man doing anything but the thing [he]484-any man had done the day before .

There was therefore no reason whatever why [the three young men who had always walked up to [[their]485-the three young men who had always walked up to their government office together Government office together]486-their government office together]485-the three young men who had always walked up to their government office together should not walk up to [it]486-their government office together together on this particular wintry and cloudy morning . Everything in that age had become mechanical , and [Government clerks]487-government clerks especially . [All those clerks]488-all those clerks assembled regularly at [[their]488-all those clerks posts]489-their posts . [Three of those clerks]490-three of those clerks always walked into [town]491-town together . [All the neighbourhood]492-all the neighbourhood knew [them]490-three of those clerks : [two of [them]490-three of those clerks]493-two of them were tall and [one short]494-one short . And on this particular morning [the short clerk]495-the short clerk was only a few seconds late to join [the other two]496-the other two as [they]496-the other two passed [his]495-the short clerk gate : [he]495-the short clerk could have overtaken [them]496-the other two in three strides ; [he]495-the short clerk could have called after [them]496-the other two easily . But [he]495-the short clerk did not .

For some reason that will never be understood until [all souls]497-all souls are judged ( if [they]497-all souls are ever judged ; the idea was at this time classed with fetish worship ) [he]495-the short clerk did not join [[his]495-the short clerk two companions]498-his two companions , but walked steadily behind [them]496-the other two . The day was dull , [their]496-the other two dress was dull , everything was dull ; but in some odd impulse [he]495-the short clerk walked through [street]499-street after [street]499-street , through district after [district]501-district , looking at the backs of [the two men]502-the two men , who would have swung round at the sound of [his]495-the short clerk voice . Now , there is a law written in the darkest of the Books of Life , and it is this : If [you]503-you look at a thing nine hundred and ninety - nine times , [you]503-you are perfectly safe ; if [you]503-you look at it the thousandth time , [you]503-you are in frightful danger of seeing it for the first time .

So [the short Government official]504-the short government official looked at the coat - tails of [the tall Government officials]505-the tall government officials , and through [street]499-street after [street]499-street , and round corner after corner , saw only coat - tails , coat - tails , and again coat - tails -- when , [he]495-the short clerk did not in the least know why , something happened to [his]495-the short clerk eyes .

[Two black dragons]508-two black dragons were walking backwards in front of [him]495-the short clerk . [Two black dragons]508-two black dragons were looking at [him]495-the short clerk with evil eyes . [The dragons]510-the dragons were walking backwards it was true , but [they]510-the dragons kept [their]510-the dragons eyes fixed on [him]495-the short clerk none the less . The eyes which [he]495-the short clerk saw were , in truth , only the two buttons at the back of a frock - coat : perhaps some traditional memory of [their]510-the dragons meaningless character gave this half - witted prominence to [their]510-the dragons gaze . The slit between the tails was the nose - line of the monster : whenever the tails flapped in the winter wind the dragons licked [their]510-the dragons lips . It was only a momentary fancy , but [the small clerk]511-the small clerk found it imbedded in [his]495-the short clerk soul ever afterwards . [He]495-the short clerk never could again think of [men in frock - coats]512-men in frock - coats except as [dragons walking backwards]513-dragons walking backwards . [He]495-the short clerk explained afterwards , quite tactfully and nicely , to [[his]495-the short clerk two official friends]514-his two official friends , that ( while feeling an inexpressible regard for each of [them]514-his two official friends ) [he]495-the short clerk could not seriously regard the face of either of [them]514-his two official friends as anything but a kind of tail . It was , [he]495-the short clerk admitted , a handsome tail -- a tail elevated in the air . But if , [he]495-the short clerk said , [any true friend of [theirs]514-his two official friends]515-any true friend of theirs wished to see [their]514-his two official friends faces , to look into the eyes of [their]514-his two official friends soul , [that friend]516-that friend must be allowed to walk reverently round behind [them]514-his two official friends , so as to see [them]514-his two official friends from the rear . There [he]495-the short clerk would see [the two black dragons with the blind eyes]517-the two black dragons with the blind eyes .

But when first the two black dragons sprang out of the fog upon [the small clerk]511-the small clerk , [they]517-the two black dragons with the blind eyes had merely the effect of all miracles -- they changed [the universe]519-the universe . [He]495-the short clerk discovered the fact that [all romantics]520-all romantics know -- that adventures happen on dull days , and not on sunny ones . When the chord of monotony is stretched most tight , then it breaks with a sound like song . [He]495-the short clerk had scarcely noticed the weather before , but with the four dead eyes glaring at [him]495-the short clerk [he]495-the short clerk looked round and realised the strange dead day .

The morning was wintry and dim , not misty , but darkened with that shadow of cloud or snow which steeps everything in a green or copper twilight . The light there is on such a day seems not so much to come from the clear heavens as to be a phosphorescence clinging to the shapes themselves . The load of heaven and the clouds is like a load of waters , and [the men]521-the men move like fishes , feeling that [they]521-the men are on the floor of [a sea]522-a sea . Everything in [a London street]523-a london street completes the fantasy ; [the carriages]524-the carriages and [cabs]525-cabs [themselves]524-the carriages resemble [deep - sea creatures with eyes of flame]526-deep - sea creatures with eyes of flame . [He]495-the short clerk had been startled at first to meet [two dragons]527-two dragons . Now [he]495-the short clerk found [he]495-the short clerk was among deep - sea dragons possessing [the deep sea]528-the deep sea .

[The two young men in front]529-the two young men in front were like [the small young man]530-the small young man [himself]530-the small young man , well - dressed . The lines of [their]529-the two young men in front frock - coats and silk hats had that luxuriant severity which makes the modern fop , hideous as [he]495-the short clerk is , a favourite exercise of [the modern draughtsman]531-the modern draughtsman ; that element which [Mr. Max Beerbohm]222-mr. max beerbohm has admirably expressed in speaking of " certain congruities of dark cloth and the rigid perfection of linen . "[222-mr. max beerbohm]

[They]529-the two young men in front walked with the gait of [an affected snail]532-an affected snail , and [they]529-the two young men in front spoke at the longest intervals , dropping a sentence at about every sixth lamp - post .

[They]529-the two young men in front crawled on past the lamp - posts ; [[their]529-the two young men in front mien]533-their mien was so immovable that a fanciful description might almost say , that the lamp - posts crawled past [the men]521-the men , as in a dream . Then [the small man]535-the small man suddenly ran after [them]529-the two young men in front and said--

" [I]535-the small man want to get [my]535-the small man hair cut . And [I]247-barker seriously believe that [he]1739-that fellow has talked nonsense so much that [he]1739-that fellow has half bewildered [his]1739-that fellow own mind and does n't know the difference between sanity and insanity . [He]1739-that fellow has gone round [the mental world]1748-the mental world , so to speak , and found the place where [the East]1749-the east and [the West]24-the west are one , and extreme idiocy is as good as sense . As [they]545-they passed up [the long streets]546-the long streets towards [[their]545-they restaurant]547-their restaurant the copper twilight cleared slowly to a pale yellow , and by the time [they]545-they reached [it]547-their restaurant [they]545-they stood discernible in a tolerable winter daylight . [The Honourable James Barker]247-barker , [one of [the most powerful officials in [the English Government]25-the english government]549-the most powerful officials in the english government]548-one of the most powerful officials in the english government ( by this time [a rigidly official one]550-a rigidly official one ) , was [a lean and elegant young man , with a blank handsome face and bleak blue eyes]551-a lean and elegant young man , with a blank handsome face and bleak blue eyes . [He]247-barker had a great amount of intellectual capacity , of that peculiar kind which raises [a man]388-a man from throne to throne and lets [him]388-a man die loaded with honours without having either amused or enlightened the mind of [a single man]553-a single man . [Wilfrid Lambert]226-lambert , [the youth with the nose which appeared to impoverish the rest of [his]226-lambert face]554-the youth with the nose which appeared to impoverish the rest of his face , had also contributed little to the enlargement of the human spirit , but [he]226-lambert had the honourable excuse of being [a fool]1742-a fool .

[Lambert]226-lambert would have been called [a silly man]556-a silly man ; [Barker]247-barker , with all [his]247-barker cleverness , might have been called [a stupid man]393-a stupid man . But mere silliness and stupidity sank into insignificance in the presence of the awful and mysterious treasures of foolishness apparently stored up in [the small figure that stood waiting for [them]559-them outside [[Cicconani]223-cicconani 's]1735-cicconani 's]558-the small figure that stood waiting for them outside cicconani 's . [The little man]561-the little man , whose name was [Auberon Quin]227-auberon , had an appearance compounded of [a baby]562-a baby and an owl . [His]561-the little man round head , round eyes , seemed to have been designed by nature playfully with a pair of compasses . " [I]227-auberon have been waiting quite a long time , "[227-auberon] said [Quin]227-auberon , mildly . " It 's awfully funny [I]227-auberon should see [you]561-the little man coming up [the street]394-the street at last . "[227-auberon]

" [[My]568-the sage mother]1751-my mother used to tell [people]1752-people to come to [places]1753-places , "[568-the sage] said [the sage]568-the sage .

[They]565-strangers were about to turn into [the restaurant]569-the restaurant with a resigned air , when [their]565-strangers eyes were caught by something in [the street]394-the street . The weather , though cold and blank , was now quite clear , and across the dull brown of [the wood pavement]571-the wood pavement and between the dull grey terraces was moving something not to be seen for miles round -- not to be seen perhaps at that time in [England]8-england -- [a man dressed in bright colours]572-a man dressed in bright colours . [A small crowd]573-a small crowd hung on [the man]574-the man 's heels .

[He]574-the man was [a tall stately man , clad in a military uniform of brilliant green , splashed with great silver facings]575-a tall stately man , clad in a military uniform of brilliant green , splashed with great silver facings . From the shoulder swung a short green furred cloak , somewhat like that of a Hussar , the lining of which gleamed every now and then with a kind of tawny crimson . [His]574-the man breast glittered with medals ; round [his]574-the man neck was the red ribbon and star of some foreign order ; and a long straight sword , with a blazing hilt , trailed and clattered along [the pavement]576-the pavement . At this time the pacific and utilitarian development of [Europe]23-europe had relegated all such customs to [the Museums]577-the museums . [The only remaining force]578-the only remaining force , [the small but well - organised police]579-the small but well - organised police , were attired in a sombre and hygienic manner . But even [those who remembered the last Life Guards]580-those who remembered the last life guards and [Lancers who disappeared in 1912]581-lancers who disappeared in 1912 must have known at a glance that this was not , and never had been , an English uniform ; and this conviction would have been heightened by the yellow aquiline face , like Dante carved in bronze , which rose , crowned with white hair , out of the green military collar , a keen and distinguished , but not an English face .

The magnificence with which [the green - clad gentleman]582-the green - clad gentleman walked down the centre of [the road]583-the road would be something difficult to express in human language . For it was an ingrained simplicity and arrogance , something in the mere carriage of the head and body , which made [ordinary moderns in [the street]394-the street]584-ordinary moderns in the street stare after [him]574-the man ; but it had comparatively little to do with actual conscious gestures or expression . In the matter of these merely temporary movements , [the man]574-the man appeared to be rather worried and inquisitive , but [he]574-the man was inquisitive with the inquisitiveness of [a despot]587-a despot and worried as with the responsibilities of [a god]588-a god . [The men who lounged and wondered behind [him]574-the man]589-the men who lounged and wondered behind him followed partly with an astonishment at [his]574-the man brilliant uniform , that is to say , partly because of that instinct which makes [us]590-us all follow one who looks like [a madman]591-a madman , but far more because of that instinct which makes [all men]592-all men follow ( and worship ) [any one who chooses to behave like [a king]594-a king]593-any one who chooses to behave like a king . [He]574-the man had to so sublime an extent that great quality of royalty -- an almost imbecile unconsciousness of [everybody]595-everybody , that [people]1752-people went after [him]574-the man as [they]1752-people do after [kings]597-kings -- to see what would be the first thing or person [he]574-the man would take notice of . And all the time , as [we]590-us have said , in spite of [his]574-the man quiet splendour , there was an air about [him]574-the man as if [he]574-the man were looking for [somebody]598-somebody ; an expression of inquiry .

Suddenly that expression of inquiry vanished , none could tell why , and was replaced by an expression of contentment . [He]600-the magnificent green gentleman came to a halt opposite to a large poster of [Colman]229-colman 's Mustard erected on a wooden hoarding . " Yes , "[609-the foreigner] said [the foreigner]609-the foreigner , snatching at the word . " [You]227-auberon are right , [generous Englishman]232-generous englishman . An idea _ brillant _ , a burning thought . Señor , [you]227-auberon asked [me]609-the foreigner why , in [my]609-the foreigner desire to see the colours of [[my]609-the foreigner country]1770-my country , [I]609-the foreigner snatched at paper and blood . Can [you]227-auberon not understand the ancient sanctity of colours ? [The Church]1771-the church has [her]1771-the church symbolic colours . And think of what colours mean to [us]1772-us -- think of the position of one like [myself]609-the foreigner , who can see nothing but those two colours , nothing but the red and the yellow . To [me]609-the foreigner all shapes are equal , all common and noble things are in a democracy of combination . Wherever there is a field of marigolds and the red cloak of [an old woman]1773-an old woman , there is [Nicaragua]26-nicaragua . Wherever there is a field of poppies and a yellow patch of sand , there is [Nicaragua]26-nicaragua . Wherever there is a lemon and a red sunset , there is [[my]609-the foreigner country]1770-my country . Wherever [I]609-the foreigner see a red pillar - box and a yellow sunset , there [my]609-the foreigner heart beats . Blood and a splash of mustard can be [my]609-the foreigner heraldry . If there be yellow mud and red mud in [the same ditch]1775-the same ditch , it is better to [me]609-the foreigner than white stars . "[609-the foreigner]

" And if , "[227-auberon] said [Quin]227-auberon , with equal enthusiasm , " there should happen to be yellow wine and red wine at the same lunch , [you]622-the amiable englishman could not confine [yourself]622-the amiable englishman to sherry . Let [me]227-auberon order some Burgundy , and complete , as it were , a sort of Nicaraguan heraldry in [your]622-the amiable englishman inside . "[227-auberon]

[Barker]247-barker was fiddling with [his]247-barker knife , and was evidently making up [his]247-barker mind to say something , with the intense nervousness of [the amiable Englishman]622-the amiable englishman .

" [I]247-barker am to understand , then , "[247-barker] [he]247-barker said at last , with a cough , " that [you]622-the amiable englishman , ahem , were [the President of [Nicaragua]26-nicaragua]619-the president of nicaragua when [it]26-nicaragua made [its]26-nicaragua -- er -- one must , of course , agree -- [its]26-nicaragua quite heroic resistance to -- er-- "[247-barker]

[The ex - President of [Nicaragua]26-nicaragua]623-the ex - president of nicaragua waved [his]247-barker hand .

" [You]622-the amiable englishman need not hesitate in speaking to [me]247-barker , "[247-barker] [he]247-barker said . "[247-barker]

" So [your]622-the amiable englishman sympathies are , "[234-del fuego] said [Del Fuego]234-del fuego , quite calmly , " with the big nation which-- "[234-del fuego]

[We]1779-we do not disapprove of the fire and extravagance of [such commonwealths as [yours]622-the amiable englishman]1783-such commonwealths as yours only to become more extravagant on a larger scale . [We]1779-we do not discourage small nationalities because [we]1779-we wish large nationalities to have all [their]1784-their smallness , all [their]1784-their uniformity of outlook , all [their]1784-their exaggeration of spirit . If [I]247-barker differ with the greatest respect from [your]622-the amiable englishman Nicaraguan enthusiasm , it is not because [a nation]1785-a nation or [ten nations]1786-ten nations were against [you]622-the amiable englishman ; it is because civilisation was against [you]622-the amiable englishman . [[We]1779-we moderns]1787-we moderns believe in a great cosmopolitan civilisation , one which shall include all the talents of [all the absorbed peoples--]1788-all the absorbed peoples-- "[247-barker]

" [The Señor]230-señor will forgive [me]624-the president , "[624-the president] said [the President]624-the president . " May [I]624-the president ask [the Señor]230-señor how , under ordinary circumstances , [he]230-señor catches a wild horse ? "[624-the president]

" [I]247-barker never catch a wild horse , "[247-barker] replied [Barker]247-barker , with dignity .

" Precisely , "[618-the other] said [the other]618-the other ; " and there ends [your]622-the amiable englishman absorption of the talents . That is what [I]618-the other complain of [your]622-the amiable englishman cosmopolitanism . When [you]622-the amiable englishman say [you]622-the amiable englishman want [all peoples]1789-all peoples to unite , [you]622-the amiable englishman really mean that [you]622-the amiable englishman want [all peoples]1789-all peoples to unite to learn the tricks of [[your]622-the amiable englishman people]1791-your people . ' [You]622-the amiable englishman say [your]622-the amiable englishman civilisation will include all talents . Will it ? [I]618-the other recur to the example [I]618-the other gave . " Something , perhaps , "[247-barker] replied [Barker]247-barker , " but that something a mere barbarian dexterity . "[247-barker]

" [You]622-the amiable englishman have good authority , "[237-the nicaraguan] answered [the Nicaraguan]237-the nicaraguan . "[237-the nicaraguan]

" [I]247-barker think [you]622-the amiable englishman do not quite understand , [President]233-president , what [ours]1804-we is , "[247-barker] answered [Barker]247-barker . " [You]622-the amiable englishman judge it rather as if [England]8-england was still [a poor and pugnacious island]1805-a poor and pugnacious island ; [you]622-the amiable englishman have been long out of [Europe]23-europe . Many things have happened . "[247-barker]

" And what , "[618-the other] asked [the other]618-the other , " would [you]622-the amiable englishman call the summary of those things ? "[618-the other]

" The summary of those things , "[247-barker] answered [Barker]247-barker , with great animation , " is that [we]1804-we are rid of the superstitions , and in becoming so [we]1804-we have not merely become rid of the superstitions which have been most frequently and most enthusiastically so described . The superstition of big nationalities is bad , but the superstition of small nationalities is worse . The superstition of reverencing [[our]1804-we own country]1806-our own country is bad , but the superstition of reverencing [[other people]1807-other people 's countries]1808-other people 's countries is worse . It is so everywhere , and in a hundred ways . The superstition of monarchy is bad , and the superstition of [aristocracy]1809-aristocracy is bad , but the superstition of democracy is the worst of all . "[247-barker]

[The old gentleman]627-the old gentleman opened [his]627-the old gentleman eyes with some surprise .

" Are [you]622-the amiable englishman , then , "[627-the old gentleman] [he]627-the old gentleman said , " no longer a democracy in [England]8-england ? "[627-the old gentleman]

[Barker]247-barker laughed .

" The situation invites paradox , "[247-barker] [he]247-barker said . " [We]1804-we are , in a sense , the purest democracy . [We]1804-we have become [a despotism]478-a despotism . Have [you]622-the amiable englishman not noticed how continually in history democracy becomes despotism ? [People]1752-people call it the decay of democracy . [It]1812-it is simply [its]1812-it fulfilment . Why take the trouble to number and register and enfranchise all the innumerable [John Robinsons]238-john robinsons , when [you]622-the amiable englishman can take one [John Robinson]239-john robinson with the same intellect or lack of intellect as [all the rest]611-all the rest , and have done with it ? [The old idealistic republicans]1814-the old idealistic republicans used to found democracy on the idea that [all men]592-all men were equally intelligent . Believe [me]247-barker , the sane and enduring democracy is founded on the fact that [all men]592-all men are equally idiotic . Why should [we]1804-we not choose out of [them]592-all men one as much as another . All that [we]1804-we want for Government is [a man not criminal and insane , who can rapidly look over some petitions and sign some proclamations]1817-a man not criminal and insane , who can rapidly look over some petitions and sign some proclamations . To think what time was wasted in arguing about [the House of Lords]1818-the house of lords , [Tories]1819-tories saying it ought to be preserved because it was clever , and [Radicals]1820-radicals saying it ought to be destroyed because it was stupid , and all the time [no one]416-no one saw that it was right because it was stupid , because that chance mob of [ordinary men thrown there by accident of blood]1822-ordinary men thrown there by accident of blood , were a great democratic protest against [the Lower House]1823-the lower house , against the eternal insolence of [the aristocracy of talents]1824-the aristocracy of talents . [We]1804-we have established now in [England]8-england , the thing towards which all systems have dimly groped , the dull popular despotism without illusions . [We]1804-we want [one man]1825-one man at the head of [[our]1804-we State]1826-our state , not because [he]1825-one man is brilliant or virtuous , but because [he]1825-one man is [one man]1825-one man and [not a chattering crowd]1828-not a chattering crowd . To avoid the possible chance of hereditary diseases or such things , [we]1804-we have abandoned hereditary monarchy . [The King of [England]8-england]1829-the king of england is chosen like [a juryman upon an official rotation list]1830-a juryman upon an official rotation list . Beyond that the whole system is quietly despotic , and [we]1804-we have not found it raise a murmur . "[247-barker]

" Do [you]247-barker really mean , "[624-the president] asked [the President]624-the president , incredulously , " that [you]247-barker choose [any ordinary man]1831-any ordinary man that comes to hand and make [him]1831-any ordinary man [despot]1832-despot -- that [you]247-barker trust to the chance of some alphabetical list .... "[624-the president]

" And why not ? "[247-barker] cried [Barker]247-barker . " Did [not half the historical nations]1833-not half the historical nations trust to the chance of [the eldest sons of [eldest sons]1835-eldest sons]1834-the eldest sons of eldest sons , and did not half of [them]1833-not half the historical nations get on tolerably well ? To have a perfect system is impossible ; to have a system is indispensable . All hereditary monarchies were a matter of luck : so are [alphabetical monarchies]1836-alphabetical monarchies . Can [you]247-barker find a deep philosophical meaning in the difference between [the Stuarts]240-the stuarts and [the Hanoverians]241-the hanoverians ? " And [you]247-barker risk it ? "[618-the other] asked [the other]618-the other . " Though [the man]574-the man may be [a tyrant]1838-a tyrant or [a cynic]1839-a cynic or [a criminal]1840-a criminal . "[618-the other]

" [We]1841-we risk it , "[247-barker] answered [Barker]247-barker , with a perfect placidity . Suppose [he]574-the man is [a cynic]1839-a cynic , it is to [his]574-the man interest to govern well . Suppose [he]574-the man is [a criminal]1840-a criminal -- by removing poverty and substituting power , [we]1841-we put a check on [his]574-the man criminality . [The Nicaraguan old gentleman]630-the nicaraguan old gentleman leaned over with a queer expression in [his]630-the nicaraguan old gentleman eyes .

[The old President]631-the old president smiled .

CHAPTER III--_The [Hill of Humour]638-hill of humour _

" In [a little square garden of yellow roses]1865-a little square garden of yellow roses , beside [the sea]1866-the sea , "[227-auberon] said [Auberon Quin]227-auberon , " there was [a Nonconformist minister who had never been to [Wimbledon]34-wimbledon]1867-a nonconformist minister who had never been to wimbledon . [[His]1867-a nonconformist minister who had never been to wimbledon family]1868-his family did not understand [his]1867-a nonconformist minister who had never been to wimbledon sorrow or the strange look in [his]1867-a nonconformist minister who had never been to wimbledon eyes . But one day [they]1868-his family repented [their]1868-his family neglect , for [they]1868-his family heard that a body had been found on [the shore]1869-the shore , battered , but wearing patent leather boots . As it happened , it turned out not to be [the minister]1870-the minister at all . But in [the dead man]1871-the dead man 's pocket there was a return ticket to [Maidstone]35-maidstone . "[227-auberon]

There was a short pause as [Quin]227-auberon and [[his]227-auberon friends]639-his friends [Barker]247-barker and [Lambert]226-lambert went swinging on through [the slushy grass of [Kensington Gardens]36-kensington gardens]640-the slushy grass of kensington gardens . Then [Auberon]227-auberon resumed .

" That story , "[227-auberon] [he]227-auberon said reverently , " is the test of humour . "[227-auberon]

[They]641-they walked on further and faster , wading through higher grass as [they]641-they began to climb [a slope]642-a slope .

" [I]227-auberon perceive , "[227-auberon] continued [Auberon]227-auberon , " that [you]247-barker have passed the test , and consider the anecdote excruciatingly funny ; since [you]247-barker say nothing . Only coarse humour is received with pot - house applause . The great anecdote is received in silence , like a benediction . [You]247-barker felt pretty benedicted , did n't [you]247-barker , [Barker]247-barker ? "[227-auberon]

" [I]247-barker saw the point , "[247-barker] said [Barker]247-barker , somewhat loftily .

" Do [you]247-barker know , "[227-auberon] said [Quin]227-auberon , with a sort of idiot gaiety , " [I]227-auberon have lots of stories as good as that . Listen to this one . "[227-auberon]

And [he]227-auberon slightly cleared [his]227-auberon throat .

" [Dr. Polycarp]243-dr. polycarp was , as [you]247-barker all know , [an unusually sallow bimetallist]1872-an unusually sallow bimetallist . ' There , ' [people of wide experience]1873-people of wide experience would say , ' There goes [the sallowest bimetallist in [Cheshire]37-cheshire]1874-the sallowest bimetallist in cheshire . ' Once this was said so that [he]227-auberon overheard it : it was said by [an actuary]1875-an actuary , under a sunset of mauve and grey . [Polycarp]243-dr. polycarp turned upon [him]227-auberon . ' [Sallow]244-sallow ! ' [he]227-auberon cried fiercely , ' sallow ! _ Quis tulerit Gracchos de seditione querentes . _ ' It was said that [no actuary]1876-no actuary ever made game of [Dr. Polycarp]243-dr. polycarp again . "[227-auberon]

[Barker]247-barker nodded with a simple sagacity . [Lambert]226-lambert only grunted .

" Here is another , "[227-auberon] continued [the insatiable Quin]227-auberon . " In [a hollow of [the grey - green hills of [rainy Ireland]38-rainy ireland]1878-the grey - green hills of rainy ireland]1877-a hollow of the grey - green hills of rainy ireland , lived [an old , old woman]1879-an old , old woman , whose uncle was always [Cambridge]245-cambridge at the Boat Race . But in [[her]1879-an old , old woman grey - green hollows]1880-her grey - green hollows , [she]1879-an old , old woman knew nothing of this : [she]1879-an old , old woman did n't know that there was a Boat Race . Also [she]1879-an old , old woman did not know that [she]1879-an old , old woman had [an uncle]1881-an uncle . [She]1879-an old , old woman had heard of [nobody at all]1882-nobody at all , except of [George the First]246-george the first , of whom [she]1879-an old , old woman had heard ( [I]227-auberon know not why ) , and in whose historical memory [she]1879-an old , old woman put [her]1879-an old , old woman simple trust . And by and by in [God]199-god 's good time , it was discovered that [this uncle of hers]1883-this uncle of hers was not really [[her]1879-an old , old woman uncle]1884-her uncle , and [they]1885-they came and told [her]1879-an old , old woman so . [She]1879-an old , old woman smiled through [her]1879-an old , old woman tears , and said only , ' Virtue is its own reward . ' "[227-auberon]

Again there was a silence , and then [Lambert]226-lambert said--

" It seems a bit mysterious . "[226-lambert]

" Mysterious ! "[618-the other] cried [the other]618-the other . " The true humour is mysterious . Do [you]618-the other not realise the chief incident of the nineteenth and twentieth centuries ? "[618-the other]

" And what 's that ? "[226-lambert] asked [Lambert]226-lambert , shortly .

" It is very simple , "[618-the other] replied [the other]618-the other . " Hitherto it was the ruin of a joke that [people]1752-people did not see it . Now it is the sublime victory of a joke that [people]1752-people do not see it . Humour , [[my]618-the other friends]1762-my friends , is the one sanctity remaining to [mankind]1889-mankind . It is the one thing [you]618-the other are thoroughly afraid of . Look at that tree . "[618-the other]

[[His]618-the other interlocutors]645-his interlocutors looked vaguely towards a beech that leant out towards [them]645-his interlocutors from [the ridge of [the hill]647-the hill]646-the ridge of the hill .

" If , "[227-auberon] said [Mr. Quin]227-auberon , " [I]648-i were to say that [you]618-the other did not see the great truths of science exhibited by that tree , though [they]1890-they stared [any man of intellect]1891-any man of intellect in the face , what would [you]618-the other think or say ? [You]618-the other would merely regard [me]648-i as [a pedant with some unimportant theory about vegetable cells]1892-a pedant with some unimportant theory about vegetable cells . If [I]648-i were to say that [you]618-the other did not see in that tree the vile mismanagement of local politics , [you]618-the other would dismiss [me]648-i as [a Socialist crank]1893-a socialist crank with some particular fad about [public parks]1894-public parks . If [I]648-i were to say that [you]618-the other were guilty of the supreme blasphemy of looking at that tree and not seeing in it a new religion , a special revelation of [God]199-god , [you]618-the other would simply say [I]648-i was [a mystic]1895-a mystic , and think no more about [me]648-i . But if"--and[648-i] [he]648-i lifted a pontifical hand--"if [I]648-i say that [you]618-the other can not see the humour of that tree , and that [I]648-i see the humour of it -- [[my]648-i God]1896-my god ! [you]618-the other will roll about at [my]648-i feet . "[648-i]

[He]648-i paused a moment , and then resumed .

" Yes ; a sense of humour , a weird and delicate sense of humour , is the new religion of [mankind]1889-mankind ! It is towards that [men]357-men will strain [themselves]357-men with the asceticism of [saints]1899-saints . Exercises , spiritual exercises , will be set in it . It will be asked , ' Can [you]618-the other see the humour of this iron railing ? ' or ' Can [you]618-the other see the humour of [this field of corn]1900-this field of corn ? Can [you]618-the other see the humour of the stars ? Can [you]618-the other see the humour of the sunsets ? ' How often [I]648-i have laughed [myself]648-i to sleep over a violet sunset . "[648-i]

" Quite so , "[247-barker] said [Mr. Barker]247-barker , with an intelligent embarrassment .

" Let [me]648-i tell [you]618-the other another story . How often it happens that [the M.P. 's for [Essex]39-essex]1901-the m.p. 's for essex are less punctual than [one]1758-one would suppose . The least punctual [Essex M.P.]248-essex m.p. , perhaps , was [James Wilson]249-james wilson , who said , in the very act of plucking a poppy-- "[648-i]

[Lambert]226-lambert suddenly faced round and struck [his]226-lambert stick into the ground in a defiant attitude .

" [Auberon]227-auberon , "[226-lambert] [he]226-lambert said , " chuck it . [I]226-lambert wo n't stand it . It 's all bosh . "[226-lambert]

[Both men]649-both men stared at [him]226-lambert , for there was something very explosive about the words , as if they had been corked up painfully for a long time .

" [You]226-lambert have , "[227-auberon] began [Quin]227-auberon , " no-- "[227-auberon]

[Barker]247-barker turned a fierce red , but continued to stare at the horizon .

"[666-the officer]

[Barker]247-barker 's eyes were blazing in [his]247-barker pale face . [He]247-barker was consumed with ambition throughout [his]247-barker life . By this time [he]227-auberon had been landed the right way up , and [the two men]502-the two men were still trying in vain to impress [him]227-auberon with the gravity of the situation .

" Did [you]502-the two men not tell [me]227-auberon , [Wilfrid Lambert]226-lambert , "[227-auberon] [he]227-auberon said , " that [I]227-auberon should be of more public value if [I]227-auberon adopted a more popular form of humour ? " The reversal of the obvious , "[1924-the king] said [the King]1924-the king , calmly , " is as near as [we]1947-we can come to ritual with [our]1947-we imperfect apparatus . Lead on . "[1924-the king]

The rest of that afternoon and evening was to [Barker]247-barker and [Lambert]226-lambert a nightmare , which [they]677-they could not properly realise or recall . BOOK II

CHAPTER I--_The Charter of [the Cities]692-the cities _

[Lambert]226-lambert was standing bewildered outside the door of [[the King]1924-the king 's apartments]694-the king 's apartments amid the scurry of astonishment and ridicule . [He]226-lambert was just passing out into [the street]394-the street , in a dazed manner , when [James Barker]247-barker dashed by [him]226-lambert .

" Where are [you]226-lambert going ? "[247-barker] [he]247-barker asked .

" To stop all this foolery , of course , "[247-barker] replied [Barker]247-barker ; and [he]247-barker disappeared into [the room]696-the room .

[He]247-barker entered [it]696-the room headlong , slamming the door , and slapping [his]247-barker incomparable silk hat on the table . [His]247-barker mouth opened , but before [he]247-barker could speak , [the King]1924-the king said--

" [Your]226-lambert hat , if [you]226-lambert please . "[1924-the king]

Fidgetting with [his]247-barker fingers , and scarcely knowing what [he]247-barker was doing , [the young politician]698-the young politician held it out .

[The King]1924-the king placed it on [his]1924-the king own chair , and sat on it .

" A quaint old custom , "[1924-the king] [he]1924-the king explained , smiling above the ruins . " When [the King]1924-the king receives [the representatives of [the House of Barker]1950-the house of barker]1949-the representatives of the house of barker , the hat of [the latter]1951-the latter is immediately destroyed in this manner . It represents the absolute finality of the act of homage expressed in the removal of it . It declares that never until that hat shall once more appear upon [your]226-lambert head ( a contingency which [I]1924-the king firmly believe to be remote ) shall [the House of [Barker]247-barker]1950-the house of barker rebel against [the Crown of [England]8-england]41-the crown of england . "[1924-the king]

[Barker]247-barker stood with clenched fist , and shaking lip .

" [Your]618-the other jokes , "[247-barker] [he]247-barker began , " and [my]247-barker property-- "[247-barker] and then exploded with an oath , and stopped again .

" Continue , continue , "[1924-the king] said [the King]1924-the king , waving [his]1924-the king hands .

" What does it all mean ? "[618-the other] cried [the other]618-the other , with a gesture of passionate rationality . " Are [you]247-barker mad ? "[618-the other]

" Not in the least , "[1924-the king] replied [the King]1924-the king , pleasantly . " [Madmen]1953-madmen are always serious ; [they]1953-madmen go mad from lack of humour . [You]247-barker are looking serious [yourself]247-barker , [James]247-barker . "[1924-the king]

" Why ca n't [you]247-barker keep it to [your]247-barker own private life ? "[618-the other] expostulated [the other]618-the other . " [You]247-barker 've got plenty of money , and plenty of [houses]1729-houses now to play [the fool]1955-the fool in , but in the interests of the public-- "[618-the other]

" Epigrammatic , "[1924-the king] said [the King]1924-the king , shaking [his]1924-the king finger sadly at [him]247-barker . " None of [your]247-barker daring scintillations here . As to why [I]1924-the king do n't do it in private , [I]1924-the king rather fail to understand [your]247-barker question . The answer is of comparative limpidity . [I]1924-the king do n't do it in private , because it is funnier to do it in public . [You]247-barker appear to think that it would be amusing to be dignified in [the banquet hall]1956-the banquet hall and in [the street]394-the street , and at [[my]1924-the king own fireside]1958-my own fireside ( [I]1924-the king could procure a fireside ) to keep the company in a roar . But that is what [every one]1959-every one does . [Every one]1959-every one is grave in public , and funny in private . [My]1924-the king sense of humour suggests the reversal of this ; it suggests that one should be funny in public , and solemn in private . [I]1924-the king desire to make the State functions , parliaments , coronations , and so on , one roaring old - fashioned pantomime . But , on the other hand , [I]1924-the king shut [myself]1924-the king up alone in [a small store - room]1961-a small store - room for two hours a day , where [I]1924-the king am so dignified that [I]1924-the king come out quite ill . "[1924-the king]

By this time [Barker]247-barker was walking up and down [the room]696-the room , [his]247-barker frock coat flapping like the black wings of a bird .

" Well , [you]247-barker will ruin [the country]449-the country , that 's all , "[247-barker] [he]247-barker said shortly .

" It seems to [me]227-auberon , "[227-auberon] said [Auberon]227-auberon , " that the tradition of ten centuries is being broken , and [the House of [Barker]247-barker]1950-the house of barker is rebelling against [the Crown of [England]8-england]41-the crown of england . It would be with regret ( for [I]227-auberon admire [your]247-barker appearance ) that [I]227-auberon should be obliged forcibly to decorate [your]247-barker head with the remains of this hat , but-- "[227-auberon]

" What [I]247-barker ca n't understand , "[247-barker] said [Barker]247-barker flinging up [his]247-barker fingers with a feverish American movement , " is why [you]247-barker do n't care about anything else but [your]247-barker games . "[247-barker]

[The King]1924-the king stopped sharply in the act of lifting the silken remnants , dropped them , and walked up to [Barker]247-barker , looking at [him]247-barker steadily .

" [I]247-barker made a kind of vow , "[247-barker] [he]247-barker said , " that [I]247-barker would not talk seriously , which always means answering silly questions . But [the strong man]1964-the strong man will always be gentle with [politicians]1965-politicians .[247-barker]

' The shape [my]0-i scornful looks deride Required [a God]588-a god to form ; '

if [I]0-i may so theologically express [myself]0-i . And for some reason [I]0-i can not in the least understand , [I]0-i feel impelled to answer that question of [yours]708-you , and to answer it as if there were really such a thing in [the world]352-the world as a serious subject . [You]708-you ask [me]0-i why [I]0-i do n't care for anything else . Can [you]708-you tell [me]0-i , in the name of all [the gods [you]708-you do n't believe in]710-the gods you do n't believe in , why [I]0-i should care for anything else ? "[708-you]

" Do n't [you]708-you realise common public necessities ? "[247-barker] cried [Barker]247-barker . " Is it possible that [a man of [your]708-you intelligence]1966-a man of your intelligence does not know that it is [every one]1959-every one 's interest-- "[247-barker]

" Do n't [you]708-you believe in [Zoroaster]42-zoroaster ? Is it possible that [you]708-you neglect [Mumbo - Jumbo]1968-mumbo - jumbo ? "[1924-the king] returned [the King]1924-the king , with startling animation . " Does [a man of [your]708-you intelligence]1966-a man of your intelligence come to [me]712-i with these damned early Victorian ethics ? If , on studying [my]712-i features and manner , [you]708-you detect any particular resemblance to [the Prince Consort]1970-the prince consort , [I]712-i assure [you]708-you [you]708-you are mistaken . Did [Herbert Spencer]225-herbert spencer ever convince [you]708-you -- did [he]225-herbert spencer ever convince [anybody]1971-anybody -- did [he]225-herbert spencer ever for one mad moment convince [himself]225-herbert spencer -- that it must be to the interest of [the individual]1972-the individual to feel a public spirit ? Do [you]708-you believe that , if [you]708-you rule [[your]708-you department]1973-your department badly , [you]708-you stand any more chance , or one half of the chance , of being guillotined , that [an angler]1974-an angler stands of being pulled into [the river]1975-the river by a strong pike ? [Herbert Spencer]225-herbert spencer refrained from theft for the same reason that [he]225-herbert spencer refrained from wearing feathers in [his]225-herbert spencer hair , because [he]225-herbert spencer was [an English gentleman with different tastes]1976-an english gentleman with different tastes . [I]712-i am [an English gentleman with different tastes]1976-an english gentleman with different tastes . [He]225-herbert spencer liked philosophy . [I]712-i like art . [He]225-herbert spencer liked writing ten books on the nature of [human society]1978-human society . [I]712-i like to see [the Lord Chamberlain]252-the lord chamberlain walking in front of [me]712-i with a piece of paper pinned to [his]252-the lord chamberlain coat - tails . It is [my]712-i humour . Are [you]708-you answered ? At any rate , [I]712-i have said [my]712-i last serious word to - day , and [my]712-i last serious word [I]712-i trust for the remainder of [my]712-i life in [this Paradise of Fools]43-this paradise of fools . The remainder of [my]712-i conversation with [you]708-you to - day , which [I]712-i trust will be long and stimulating , [I]712-i propose to conduct in a new language of [my]712-i own by means of rapid and symbolic movements of the left leg . "[712-i] And [he]712-i began to pirouette slowly round [the room]696-the room with a preoccupied expression .

[Barker]247-barker ran round [the room]696-the room after [him]712-i , bombarding [him]712-i with demands and entreaties . But [he]712-i received no response except in the new language . [He]712-i came out banging the door again , and sick like [a man coming on shore]715-a man coming on shore . As [he]712-i strode along [the streets]359-the streets [he]712-i found [himself]712-i suddenly opposite [[Cicconani]223-cicconani 's restaurant]717-cicconani 's restaurant , and for some reason there rose up before [him]712-i the green fantastic figure of [the Spanish General]718-the spanish general , standing , as [he]712-i had seen [him]718-the spanish general last , at the door , with the words on [his]718-the spanish general lips , " [You]1979-you can not argue with the choice of the soul . "[718-the spanish general]

[The King]1924-the king came out from [his]1924-the king dancing with the air of [a man of business legitimately tired]720-a man of business legitimately tired . [He]1924-the king put on an overcoat , lit a cigar , and went out into the purple night .

" [I]1924-the king will go , "[1924-the king] [he]1924-the king said , " and mingle with [the people]447-the people . "[1924-the king]
