[ Illustration : [KING AUBERON]261-auberon DESCENDED FROM [THE OMNIBUS WITH DIGNITY]322-the omnibus with dignity . ]

[King Auberon]261-auberon descended from [the omnibus]1453-the omnibus with dignity . [The guard or picket of [red halberdiers who had stopped [the vehicle]830-the vehicle]1458-red halberdiers who had stopped the vehicle]1457-the guard or picket of red halberdiers who had stopped the vehicle did not number more than twenty , and [they]1457-the guard or picket of red halberdiers who had stopped the vehicle were under the command of [a short , dark , clever - looking young man]1460-a short , dark , clever - looking young man , conspicuous among the rest as being clad in an ordinary frock - coat , but girt round the waist with a red sash and a long seventeenth - century sword . A shiny silk hat and spectacles completed the outfit in a pleasing manner .

" To whom have [I]1924-the king the honour of speaking ? "[1924-the king] said [the King]1924-the king , endeavouring to look like [Charles]323-charles [I.]323-charles , in spite of personal difficulties .

[The dark man in spectacles]1462-the dark man in spectacles lifted [his]1462-the dark man in spectacles hat with equal gravity .

" [My]1462-the dark man in spectacles name is [Bowles]296-mr. bowles , "[1462-the dark man in spectacles] [he]1462-the dark man in spectacles said . " [I]1462-the dark man in spectacles am [a chemist]1111-a chemist . [I]1462-the dark man in spectacles am also [a captain of O company of [the army of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill]2924-the army of notting hill]2923-a captain of o company of the army of notting hill . [I]1462-the dark man in spectacles am distressed at having to incommode [you]2925-you by stopping [the omnibus]1453-the omnibus , but [this area]2927-this area is covered by [our]2928-our proclamation , and [we]2928-our intercept all traffic . May [I]1462-the dark man in spectacles ask to whom [I]1462-the dark man in spectacles have the honour -- Why , good gracious , [I]1462-the dark man in spectacles beg [[your]2925-you Majesty]1946-your majesty 's pardon . [I]1462-the dark man in spectacles am quite overwhelmed at finding [myself]1462-the dark man in spectacles concerned with [the King]1924-the king . "[1462-the dark man in spectacles]

[Auberon]261-auberon put up [his]261-auberon hand with indescribable grandeur .

" Not with [the King]1924-the king , "[261-auberon] [he]261-auberon said ; " with [the special war correspondent of the _ Court Journal _]2932-the special war correspondent of the _ court journal _ . "[261-auberon]

" [I]296-mr. bowles beg [[your]2925-you Majesty]1946-your majesty 's pardon , "[296-mr. bowles] began [Mr. Bowles]296-mr. bowles , doubtfully .

" Do [you]2925-you call [me]261-auberon [Majesty]2934-majesty ? [I]261-auberon repeat , "[261-auberon] said [Auberon]261-auberon , firmly , " [I]261-auberon am [a representative of the press]2935-a representative of the press . [I]261-auberon have chosen , with a deep sense of responsibility , the name of [Pinker]324-mr. pinker . [I]261-auberon should desire a veil to be drawn over the past . "[261-auberon]

" Very well , [sir]1754-sir , "[296-mr. bowles] said [Mr. Bowles]296-mr. bowles , with an air of submission , " in [our]2937-we eyes the sanctity of the press is at least as great as that of [the throne]2938-the throne . [We]2937-we desire nothing better than that [our]2937-we wrongs and [our]2937-we glories should be widely known . May [I]296-mr. bowles ask , [Mr. Pinker]324-mr. pinker , if [you]324-mr. pinker have any objection to being presented to [the Provost]876-the provost and to [General Turnbull]325-turnbull ? "[296-mr. bowles]

" [The Provost]876-the provost [I]261-auberon have had the honour of meeting , "[261-auberon] said [Auberon]261-auberon , easily . " [[We]2937-we old journalists]2941-we old journalists , [you]324-mr. pinker know , meet [everybody]595-everybody . [I]261-auberon should be most delighted to have the same honour again . [General Turnbull]325-turnbull , also , it would be a gratification to know . [The younger men]2943-the younger men are so interesting . [[We]2937-we of [the old Fleet Street gang]2945-the old fleet street gang]2944-we of the old fleet street gang lose touch with [them]2943-the younger men . "[261-auberon]

" Will [you]324-mr. pinker be so good as to step this way ? "[1463-the leader of o company] said [the leader of [O company]1464-o company]1463-the leader of o company .

" [I]324-mr. pinker am always good , "[324-mr. pinker] said [Mr. Pinker]324-mr. pinker . " Lead on . "[324-mr. pinker]

CHAPTER III--_The Great Army of [South Kensington]56-south kensington _

The article from [the special correspondent of the _ Court Journal]1465-the special correspondent of the _ court journal _ arrived in due course , written on very coarse copy - paper in the King 's arabesque of handwriting , in which three words filled a page , and yet were illegible . Moreover , the contribution was the more perplexing at first , as it opened with a succession of erased paragraphs . [The writer]1466-the writer appeared to have attempted the article once or twice in several journalistic styles . At the side of one experiment was written , " Try American style , "[1466-the writer] and the fragment began--

" [The King]1924-the king must go . [We]2937-we want [gritty men]2947-gritty men . Flapdoodle is all very ... ; "[1466-the writer] and then broke off , followed by the note , " Good sound journalism safer . Try it . "[1466-the writer]

The experiment in good sound journalism appeared to begin--

" [The greatest of English poets]2948-the greatest of english poets has said that a rose by any ... "[1466-the writer]

This also stopped abruptly . The next annotation at the side was almost undecipherable , but seemed to be something like--

" How about [old Steevens]326-old steevens and the _ mot juste _ ? E.g .... "[1466-the writer]

" [Morning]327-morning winked a little wearily at [me]1466-the writer over [the curt edge of [Campden Hill]164-campden hill]2949-the curt edge of campden hill and [[its]164-campden hill houses]2950-its houses with [their]2950-its houses sharp shadows . Under the abrupt black cardboard of the outline , it took some little time to detect colours ; but at length [I]1466-the writer saw a brownish yellow shifting in the obscurity , and [I]1466-the writer knew that it was [the guard of [Swindon 's West Kensington army]2952-swindon 's west kensington army]2951-the guard of swindon 's west kensington army . [They]2952-swindon 's west kensington army are being held as a reserve , and lining [the whole ridge above [the Bayswater Road]2954-the bayswater road]2953-the whole ridge above the bayswater road . [[Their]2952-swindon 's west kensington army camp]2955-their camp and [[their]2952-swindon 's west kensington army main force]2956-their main force is under [the great Waterworks Tower]2957-the great waterworks tower on [Campden Hill]164-campden hill . [I]1466-the writer forgot to say that [the Waterworks Tower]2958-the waterworks tower looked swart .[1466-the writer]

" As [I]1466-the writer passed [them]2952-swindon 's west kensington army and came over [the curve of [Silver Street]165-silver street]2959-the curve of silver street , [I]1466-the writer saw [the blue cloudy masses of [[Barker]247-barker 's men]2961-barker 's men]2960-the blue cloudy masses of barker 's men blocking the entrance to [the high - road]2962-the high - road like a sapphire smoke ( good ) . The disposition of [the allied troops]2963-the allied troops , under the general management of [Mr. Wilson]274-wilson , appears to be as follows : The Yellow army ( if [I]1466-the writer may so describe [the West Kensingtonians]2964-the west kensingtonians ) lies , as [I]1466-the writer have said , in a strip along [the ridge]652-the ridge , [its]164-campden hill furthest point westward being the west side of [Campden Hill Road]166-campden hill road , [its]164-campden hill furthest point eastward the beginning of [Kensington Gardens]36-kensington gardens . [The Green army of [Wilson]274-wilson]2966-the green army of wilson lines [the Notting Hill High Road]167-the notting hill high road [itself]167-the notting hill high road from [Queen 's Road]149-queen 's road to [the corner of [Pembridge Road]148-pembridge road]2967-the corner of pembridge road , curving round the latter , and extending some three hundred yards up towards [Westbourne Grove]84-westbourne grove . [Westbourne Grove]84-westbourne grove [itself]84-westbourne grove is occupied by [Barker of [South Kensington]56-south kensington]2968-barker of south kensington . The fourth side of [this rough square]2969-this rough square , [the Queen 's Road side]2970-the queen 's road side , is held by [some of [[Buck]320-buck 's Purple warriors]2972-buck 's purple warriors]2971-some of buck 's purple warriors .[1466-the writer]

" The whole resembles some ancient and dainty Dutch flower - bed . Along [the crest of [Campden Hill]164-campden hill]2973-the crest of campden hill lie [the golden crocuses of [West Kensington]73-west kensington]2974-the golden crocuses of west kensington . [They]2974-the golden crocuses of west kensington are , as it were , the first fiery fringe of [the whole]2975-the whole . Northward lies [[our]2976-our hyacinth Barker]247-barker , with all [his]247-barker blue hyacinths . Round to the south - west run the green rushes of [[Wilson]274-wilson of [Bayswater]54-bayswater]274-wilson , and a line of violet irises ( aptly symbolised by [Mr. Buck]273-buck ) complete the whole . The argent exterior ... ( [I]1466-the writer am losing the style . [I]1466-the writer should have said ' Curving with a whisk ' instead of merely ' Curving . ' Also [I]1466-the writer should have called [the hyacinths]2977-the hyacinths ' sudden . ' [I]1466-the writer can not keep this up . War is too rapid for this style of writing . Please ask [office - boy]2978-office - boy to insert _ mots justes _ . )[1466-the writer]

" The truth is that there is nothing to report . That commonplace element which is always ready to devour all beautiful things ( as the Black Pig in the Irish Mythology will finally devour the stars and gods ) ; that commonplace element , as [I]1466-the writer say , has in its Black Piggish way devoured finally the chances of any romance in this affair ; that which once consisted of absurd but thrilling combats in [the streets]359-the streets , has degenerated into something which is the very prose of warfare -- it has degenerated into a siege . A siege may be defined as a peace plus the inconvenience of war . Of course [Wayne]290-wayne can not hold out . There is no more chance of help from anywhere else than of [ships]2980-ships from the moon . And if [old Wayne]290-wayne had stocked [[his]290-wayne street]2981-his street with tinned meats till [all [his]290-wayne garrison]2982-all his garrison had to sit on them , [he]290-wayne could n't hold out for more than a month or two . As a matter of melancholy fact , [he]290-wayne has done something rather like this . [He]290-wayne has stocked [[his]290-wayne street]2981-his street with food until there must be uncommonly little room to turn round . But what is the good ? To hold out for all that time and then to give in of necessity , what does it mean ? It means waiting until [your]2984-your victories are forgotten , and then taking the trouble to be defeated . [I]1466-the writer can not understand how [Wayne]290-wayne can be so inartistic .[1466-the writer]

" And how odd it is that one views a thing quite differently when [one]1758-one knows it is defeated ! [I]1466-the writer always thought [Wayne]290-wayne was rather fine . But now , when [I]1466-the writer know that [he]290-wayne is done for , there seem to be nothing else but [Wayne]290-wayne . [All the streets]2986-all the streets seem to point at [him]290-wayne , [all the chimneys]2987-all the chimneys seem to lean towards [him]290-wayne . [I]1466-the writer suppose it is a morbid feeling ; but [Pump Street]88-pump street seems to be [the only part of [London]17-london]2988-the only part of london that [I]1466-the writer feel physically . [I]1466-the writer suppose , [I]1466-the writer say , that it is morbid . [I]1466-the writer suppose it is exactly how [a man]388-a man feels about [his]388-a man heart when [his]388-a man heart is weak . ' Pump Street'--the heart is a pump . And [I]1466-the writer am drivelling .[1466-the writer]

" [[Our]2990-our finest leader at the front]2991-our finest leader at the front is , beyond all question , [General Wilson]328-wilson . [He]328-wilson has adopted alone among [the other Provosts]2992-the other provosts the uniform of [[his]328-wilson own halberdiers]2993-his own halberdiers , although that fine old sixteenth - century garb was not originally intended to go with red side - whiskers . It was [he]328-wilson who , against a most admirable and desperate defence , broke last night into [Pump Street]88-pump street and held it for at least half an hour . [He]328-wilson was afterwards expelled from [it]88-pump street by [General Turnbull]325-turnbull , of [Notting Hill]2269-notting hill , but only after desperate fighting and the sudden descent of that terrible darkness which proved so much more fatal to the forces of [General Buck]320-buck and [General Swindon]305-swindon .[1466-the writer]

" [Provost Wayne]280-wayne [himself]280-wayne , with whom [I]1466-the writer had , with great good fortune , a most interesting interview , bore the most eloquent testimony to the conduct of [General Wilson]328-wilson and [[his]328-wilson men]2793-his men . [His]280-wayne precise words are as follows : ' [I]1466-the writer have bought sweets at [[his]280-wayne funny little shop]2996-his funny little shop when [I]1466-the writer was four years old , and ever since . [I]1466-the writer never noticed anything , [I]1466-the writer am ashamed to say , except that [he]280-wayne talked through [his]280-wayne nose , and did n't wash [himself]280-wayne particularly . And [he]280-wayne came over [[our]2997-our barricade]2998-our barricade like a devil from hell . ' [I]1466-the writer repeated this speech to [General Wilson]328-wilson [himself]328-wilson , with some delicate improvements , and [he]328-wilson seemed pleased with it . [He]328-wilson does not , however , seem pleased with anything so much just now as [he]328-wilson is with the wearing of a sword . [I]1466-the writer have it from the front on the best authority that [General Wilson]328-wilson was not completely shaved yesterday . It is believed in military circles that [he]328-wilson is growing a moustache ....[1466-the writer]

" As [I]1466-the writer have said , there is nothing to report . [I]1466-the writer walk wearily to the pillar - box at [the corner of [Pembridge Road]148-pembridge road]2967-the corner of pembridge road to post [my]1466-the writer copy . Nothing whatever has happened , except the preparations for a particularly long and feeble siege , during which [I]1466-the writer trust [I]1466-the writer shall not be required to be at [the Front]3000-the front . As [I]1466-the writer glance up [Pembridge Road]148-pembridge road in the growing dusk , the aspect of [that road]2822-that road reminds [me]1466-the writer that there is one note worth adding . [General Buck]320-buck has suggested , with characteristic acumen , to [General Wilson]328-wilson that , in order to obviate the possibility of such a catastrophe as overwhelmed [the allied forces in the last advance on [Notting Hill]2-notting hill]3002-the allied forces in the last advance on notting hill ( the catastrophe , [I]1466-the writer mean , of the extinguished lamps ) , [each soldier]3003-each soldier should have a lighted lantern round [his]3003-each soldier neck . This is one of the things which [I]1466-the writer really admire about [General Buck]320-buck . [He]320-buck possesses what [people]1752-people used to mean by ' the humility of [the man of science]3005-the man of science , ' that is , [he]320-buck learns steadily from [his]320-buck mistakes . [Wayne]280-wayne may score off [him]320-buck in some other way , but not in that way . The lanterns look like fairy lights as they curve round the end of [Pembridge Road]148-pembridge road .[1466-the writer]

* * * * *

" _ Later_.--I write with some difficulty , because the blood will run down [my]1466-the writer face and make patterns on the paper . Blood is a very beautiful thing ; that is why it is concealed . If [you]3006-you ask why blood runs down [my]1466-the writer face , [I]1466-the writer can only reply that [I]1466-the writer was kicked by a horse . If [you]3006-you ask [me]1466-the writer what horse , [I]1466-the writer can reply with some pride that it was a war - horse . If [you]3006-you ask [me]1466-the writer how a war - horse came on the scene in [our]3007-our simple pedestrian warfare , [I]1466-the writer am reduced to the necessity , so painful to [a special correspondent]3008-a special correspondent , of recounting [my]1466-the writer experiences .[1466-the writer]

" [I]1466-the writer was , as [I]1466-the writer have said , in the very act of posting [my]1466-the writer copy at the pillar - box , and of glancing as [I]1466-the writer did so up the glittering curve of [Pembridge Road]148-pembridge road , studded with the lights of [[Wilson]328-wilson 's men]3009-wilson 's men . [I]1466-the writer do n't know what made [me]1466-the writer pause to examine the matter , but [I]1466-the writer had a fancy that the line of lights , where it melted into the indistinct brown twilight , was more indistinct than usual . [I]1466-the writer was almost certain that in a certain stretch of [the road]583-the road where there had been five lights there were now only four . [I]1466-the writer strained [my]1466-the writer eyes ; [I]1466-the writer counted them again , and there were only three . A moment after there were only two ; an instant after only one ; and an instant after that the lanterns near to [me]1466-the writer swung like jangled bells , as if struck suddenly . They flared and fell ; and for the moment the fall of them was like the fall of the sun and stars out of heaven . It left everything in a primal blindness . As a matter of fact , [the road]583-the road was not yet legitimately dark . There were still red rays of a sunset in the sky , and the brown gloaming was still warmed , as it were , with a feeling as of firelight . But for three seconds after the lanterns swung and sank , [I]1466-the writer saw in front of [me]1466-the writer a blackness blocking the sky . And with the fourth second [I]1466-the writer knew that this blackness which blocked the sky was [a man on a great horse]3012-a man on a great horse ; and [I]1466-the writer was trampled and tossed aside as a swirl of horsemen swept round the corner . As [they]3013-they turned [I]1466-the writer saw that [they]3013-they were not black , but scarlet ; [they]3013-they were [a sortie of the besieged]3014-a sortie of the besieged , [Wayne]280-wayne riding ahead .[1466-the writer]

" [I]1466-the writer lifted [myself]1466-the writer from the gutter , blinded with blood from a very slight skin - wound , and , queerly enough , not caring either for the blindness or for the slightness of the wound . For one mortal minute after that amazing cavalcade had spun past , there was dead stillness on [the empty road]3015-the empty road . And then came [Barker]247-barker and all [his]247-barker halberdiers running like devils in the track of [them]3013-they . It had been [their]3013-they business to guard the gate by which [the sortie]3016-the sortie had broken out ; but [they]3013-they had not reckoned , and small blame to [them]3013-they , on [cavalry]3017-cavalry . As it was , [Barker]247-barker and [[his]247-barker men]2793-his men made a perfectly splendid run after [them]3013-they , almost catching [Wayne]280-wayne 's horses by the tails .[1466-the writer]

" [Nobody]2751-nobody can understand the sortie . It consists only of [a small number of [[Wayne]280-wayne 's garrison]3021-wayne 's garrison]3020-a small number of wayne 's garrison . [Turnbull]325-turnbull [himself]325-turnbull , with the vast mass of it , is undoubtedly still barricaded in [Pump Street]88-pump street . Sorties of this kind are natural enough in the majority of historical sieges , such as the siege of [Paris]170-paris in 1870 , because in such cases [the besieged]1130-the besieged are certain of some support outside . But what can be the object of it in this case ? [Wayne]280-wayne knows ( or if [he]280-wayne is too mad to know anything , at least [Turnbull]325-turnbull knows ) that there is not , and never has been , the smallest chance of support for [him]280-wayne outside ; that [the mass of [the sane modern inhabitants of [London]17-london]3024-the sane modern inhabitants of london]3023-the mass of the sane modern inhabitants of london regard [his]280-wayne farcical patriotism with as much contempt as [they]3023-the mass of the sane modern inhabitants of london do the original idiotcy that gave it birth -- the folly of [[our]3025-we miserable King]3026-our miserable king . What [Wayne]280-wayne and [[his]280-wayne horsemen]3027-his horsemen are doing [nobody]2751-nobody can even conjecture . The general theory round here is that [he]280-wayne is simply [a traitor]3029-a traitor , and has abandoned [the besieged]1130-the besieged . But all such larger but yet more soluble riddles are as nothing compared to the one small but unanswerable riddle : Where did [they]1130-the besieged get the horses ?[1466-the writer]

* * * * *

" _ Later_.--I have heard a most extraordinary account of the origin of the appearance of the horses . It appears that [that amazing person]3031-that amazing person , [General Turnbull]325-turnbull , who is now ruling [Pump Street]88-pump street in the absence of [Wayne]280-wayne , sent out , on the morning of the declaration of war , [a vast number of [little boys]3033-little boys ( or cherubs of the gutter , as [[we]3025-we pressmen]3034-we pressmen say ) , with half - crowns in [their]3032-a vast number of little boys ( or cherubs of the gutter , as we pressmen say ) , with half - crowns in their pockets , to take cabs all over london pockets , to take cabs all over [London]17-london]3032-a vast number of little boys ( or cherubs of the gutter , as we pressmen say ) , with half - crowns in their pockets , to take cabs all over london . No less than a hundred and sixty cabs met at [Pump Street]88-pump street ; were commandeered by [the garrison]1124-the garrison . [The men]521-the men were set free , the cabs used to make barricades , and the horses kept in [Pump Street]88-pump street , where [they]521-the men were fed and exercised for several days , until [they]521-the men were sufficiently rapid and efficient to be used for this wild ride out of [the town]348-the town . If this is so , and [I]1466-the writer have it on the best possible authority , the method of the sortie is explained . But [we]3025-we have no explanation of its object . Just as [Barker]247-barker 's Blues were swinging round the corner after [them]521-the men , [they]521-the men were stopped , but not by [an enemy]3038-an enemy ; only by the voice of [one man]1825-one man , and [he]1825-one man [a friend]1100-a friend . [Red Wilson of [Bayswater]54-bayswater]3041-red wilson of bayswater ran alone along [the main road]3042-the main road like [a madman]591-a madman , waving [them]521-the men back with a halberd snatched from [a sentinel]3044-a sentinel . [He]3041-red wilson of bayswater was in supreme command , and [Barker]247-barker stopped at the corner , staring and bewildered . [We]3025-we could hear [Wilson]328-wilson 's voice loud and distinct out of the dusk , so that it seemed strange that the great voice should come out of the little body . ' Halt , [South Kensington]56-south kensington ! Guard this entry , and prevent [them]521-the men returning . [I]1466-the writer will pursue . Forward , [the Green Guards]3045-the green guards ! '[1466-the writer]

" [A wall of dark blue uniforms and a wood of pole - axes]3046-a wall of dark blue uniforms and a wood of pole - axes was between [me]1466-the writer and [Wilson]328-wilson , for [[Barker]247-barker 's men]2961-barker 's men blocked [the mouth of [the road]583-the road]3048-the mouth of the road in two rigid lines . But through [them]2961-barker 's men and through the dusk [I]1466-the writer could hear the clear orders and the clank of arms , and see [the green army of [Wilson]328-wilson]2966-the green army of wilson marching by towards the west . [They]2961-barker 's men were [[our]3025-we great fighting - men]3051-our great fighting - men . [Wilson]328-wilson had filled [them]2961-barker 's men with [his]328-wilson own fire ; in a few days [they]2961-barker 's men had become [veterans]3052-veterans . [Each of [them]2961-barker 's men]3053-each of them wore a silver medal of a pump , to boast that [they]2961-barker 's men alone of all [the allied armies]3054-the allied armies had stood victorious in [Pump Street]88-pump street .[1466-the writer]

" [I]1466-the writer managed to slip past [the detachment of [Barker]247-barker 's Blues , who are guarding [the end of [Pembridge Road]148-pembridge road]3056-the end of pembridge road]3055-the detachment of barker 's blues , who are guarding the end of pembridge road , and a sharp spell of running brought [me]1466-the writer to the tail of [[Wilson]328-wilson 's green army]3057-wilson 's green army as [it]3057-wilson 's green army swung down [the road]583-the road in pursuit of [the flying Wayne]280-wayne . The dusk had deepened into almost total darkness ; for some time [I]1466-the writer only heard the throb of the marching pace . Then suddenly there was a cry , and [the tall fighting men]3059-the tall fighting men were flung back on [me]1466-the writer , almost crushing [me]1466-the writer , and again the lanterns swung and jingled , and the cold nozzles of great horses pushed into the press of [us]3060-us . [They]3059-the tall fighting men had turned and charged [us]3060-us .[1466-the writer]

" ' [[You]3060-us fools]3061-you fools ! ' came the voice of [Wilson]328-wilson , cleaving [our]3060-us panic with a splendid cold anger . ' Do n't [you]3060-us see ? the horses have [no riders]3062-no riders ! '[1466-the writer]

" It was true . [We]3060-us were being plunged at by [a stampede of horses with empty saddles]3063-a stampede of horses with empty saddles . What could it mean ? Had [Wayne]280-wayne met [some of [[our]3060-us men]3065-our men]3064-some of our men and been defeated ? Or had [he]280-wayne flung these horses at [us]3060-us as some kind of ruse or mad new mode of warfare , such as [he]280-wayne seemed bent on inventing ? Or did [he]280-wayne and [[his]280-wayne men]2793-his men want to get away in disguise ? Or did [they]3059-the tall fighting men want to hide in [houses somewhere]3067-houses somewhere ?[1466-the writer]

" Never did [I]1466-the writer admire [any man]484-any man 's intellect ( even [my]1466-the writer own ) so much as [I]1466-the writer did [Wilson]328-wilson 's at that moment . Without a word , [he]328-wilson simply pointed the halberd ( which [he]328-wilson still grasped ) to the southern side of [the road]583-the road . As [you]3070-you know , the streets running up to [the ridge of [Campden Hill]164-campden hill]3071-the ridge of campden hill from [the main road]3042-the main road are peculiarly steep , they are more like sudden flights of stairs . [We]3060-us were just opposite [Aubrey Road]171-aubrey road , the steepest of all ; up that it would have been far more difficult to urge half - trained horses than to run up on one 's feet .[1466-the writer]

" ' Left wheel ! ' hallooed [Wilson]328-wilson . ' [They]3059-the tall fighting men have gone up here , ' [he]328-wilson added to [me]1466-the writer , who happened to be at [his]328-wilson elbow .[1466-the writer]

" ' Why ? ' [I]1466-the writer ventured to ask .[1466-the writer]

" ' Ca n't say for certain , ' replied [the Bayswater General]3073-the bayswater general . ' [They]3059-the tall fighting men 've gone up here in a great hurry , anyhow . [They]3059-the tall fighting men 've simply turned [their]3059-the tall fighting men horses loose , because [they]3059-the tall fighting men could n't take [them]3059-the tall fighting men up . [I]1466-the writer fancy [I]1466-the writer know . [I]1466-the writer fancy [they]3059-the tall fighting men 're trying to get over [the ridge]652-the ridge to [Kensingston]172-kensingston or [Hammersmith]63-hammersmith , or somewhere , and are striking up here because it 's just beyond the end of [our]3075-our line . [Damned fools]3076-damned fools , not to have gone further along [the road]583-the road , though . [They]3059-the tall fighting men 've only just shaved [[our]3075-our last outpost]3078-our last outpost . [Lambert]226-lambert is hardly four hundred yards from [here]3079-here . And [I]1466-the writer 've sent [him]226-lambert word . '[1466-the writer]

" ' [Lambert]226-lambert ! ' [I]1466-the writer said . ' Not [young Wilfrid Lambert]226-lambert -- [[my]1466-the writer old friend]2178-my old friend . '[1466-the writer]

" ' [Wilfrid Lambert]226-lambert 's [his]226-lambert name , ' said [the General]3081-the general ; ' used to be [a "[1466-the writer] man about [town]491-town]3082-a " man about town ; " [silly fellow with a big nose]3083-silly fellow with a big nose . [That kind of man]3084-that kind of man always volunteers for some war or other ; and what 's funnier , [he]226-lambert generally is n't half bad at it . [Lambert]226-lambert is distinctly good . The yellow West Kensingtons [I]1466-the writer always reckoned [the weakest part of [the army]3086-the army]3085-the weakest part of the army ; but [he]226-lambert has pulled [them]3085-the weakest part of the army together uncommonly well , though [he]226-lambert 's subordinate to [Swindon]305-swindon , who 's a donkey . In the attack from [Pembridge Road]148-pembridge road the other night [he]226-lambert showed great pluck . '[1466-the writer]

" ' [He]226-lambert has shown greater pluck than that , ' [I]1466-the writer said . ' [He]226-lambert has criticised [my]1466-the writer sense of humour . That was [his]226-lambert first engagement . '[1466-the writer]

" This remark was , [I]1466-the writer am sorry to say , lost on [the admirable commander of [the allied forces]3088-the allied forces]3087-the admirable commander of the allied forces . [We]3089-we were in the act of climbing the last half of [Aubrey Road]171-aubrey road , which is so abrupt a slope that [it]3090-it looks like an old - fashioned map leaning up against the wall . There are lines of little trees , one above the other , as in the old - fashioned map .[1466-the writer]

" [We]3089-we reached the top of [it]3090-it , panting somewhat , and were just about to turn the corner by [a place called ( in chivalrous anticipation of [our]3089-we wars of sword and axe ) [Tower Creçy]173-tower creçy]3091-a place called ( in chivalrous anticipation of our wars of sword and axe ) tower creçy , when [we]3089-we were suddenly knocked in the stomach ( [I]1466-the writer can use no other term ) by [a horde of men hurled back upon [us]3089-we]3092-a horde of men hurled back upon us . [They]3092-a horde of men hurled back upon us wore the red uniform of [Wayne]280-wayne ; [their]3092-a horde of men hurled back upon us halberds were broken ; [their]3092-a horde of men hurled back upon us foreheads bleeding ; but the mere impetus of [their]3092-a horde of men hurled back upon us retreat staggered [us]3089-we as [we]3089-we stood at the last ridge of the slope .[1466-the writer]

" ' Good old [Lambert]226-lambert ! ' yelled out suddenly [the stolid Mr. Wilson of [Bayswater]54-bayswater]3093-the stolid mr. wilson of bayswater , in an uncontrollable excitement . ' [Damned jolly old Lambert]226-lambert ! [He]226-lambert 's got [there]3094-there already ! [He]226-lambert 's driving [them]3092-a horde of men hurled back upon us back on [us]3089-we ! [Hurrah]174-hurrah ! hurrah ! Forward , [the Green Guards]3045-the green guards ! '[1466-the writer]

" [We]3089-we swung round the corner eastwards , [Wilson]328-wilson running first , brandishing the halberd--[1466-the writer]

" Will [you]3096-you pardon a little egotism ? [Every one]1959-every one likes a little egotism , when it takes the form , as [mine]328-wilson does in this case , of a disgraceful confession . The thing is really a little interesting , because it shows how the merely artistic habit has bitten into [[men]357-men like [me]1466-the writer]3099-men like me . It was the most intensely exciting occurrence that had ever come to [me]1466-the writer in [my]1466-the writer life ; and [I]1466-the writer was really intensely excited about it . And yet , as [we]3089-we turned that corner , the first impression [I]1466-the writer had was of something that had nothing to do with the fight at all . [I]1466-the writer was stricken from the sky as by a thunderbolt , by the height of [the Waterworks Tower]175-the waterworks tower on [Campden Hill]164-campden hill . [I]1466-the writer do n't know whether [Londoners]814-londoners generally realise how high it looks when one comes out , in this way , almost immediately under it . For the second it seemed to [me]1466-the writer that at the foot of it even human war was a triviality . For the second [I]1466-the writer felt as if [I]1466-the writer had been drunk with some trivial orgie , and that [I]1466-the writer had been sobered by the shock of that shadow . A moment afterwards , [I]1466-the writer realised that under it was going on something more enduring than stone , and something wilder than the dizziest height -- the agony of [man]384-man . And [I]1466-the writer knew that , compared to that , [this overwhelming tower]3102-this overwhelming tower was itself a triviality ; it was a mere stalk of stone which [humanity]3103-humanity could snap like a stick .[1466-the writer]

" [I]1466-the writer do n't know why [I]1466-the writer have talked so much about [this silly old Waterworks Tower]3104-this silly old waterworks tower , which at the very best was only a tremendous background . It was that , certainly , a sombre and awful landscape , against which [our]3089-we figures were relieved . But [I]1466-the writer think the real reason was , that there was in [my]1466-the writer own mind so sharp a transition from the tower of stone to [the man of flesh]3105-the man of flesh . For what [I]1466-the writer saw first when [I]1466-the writer had shaken off , as it were , the shadow of [the tower]3106-the tower , was [a man]388-a man , and [a man [I]1466-the writer knew]3108-a man i knew .[1466-the writer]

" [Lambert]226-lambert stood at the further corner of [the street]394-the street that curved round [the tower]3106-the tower , [his]226-lambert figure outlined in some degree by the beginning of moonrise . [He]226-lambert looked magnificent , [a hero]3111-a hero ; but [he]226-lambert looked something much more interesting than that . [He]226-lambert was , as it happened , in almost precisely the same swaggering attitude in which [he]226-lambert had stood nearly fifteen years ago , when [he]226-lambert swung [his]226-lambert walking - stick and struck it into the ground , and told [me]1466-the writer that all [my]1466-the writer subtlety was drivel . And , upon [my]1466-the writer soul , [I]1466-the writer think [he]226-lambert required more courage to say that than to fight as [he]226-lambert does now . For then [he]226-lambert was fighting against something that was in the ascendant , fashionable , and victorious . And now [he]226-lambert is fighting ( at the risk of [his]226-lambert life , no doubt ) merely against something which is already dead , which is impossible , futile ; of which nothing has been more impossible and futile than this very sortie which has brought [him]226-lambert into contact with it . [People]1752-people nowadays allow infinitely too little for the psychological sense of victory as a factor in affairs . Then [he]226-lambert was attacking [the degraded but undoubtedly victorious Quin]3113-the degraded but undoubtedly victorious quin ; now [he]226-lambert is attacking [the interesting but totally extinguished Wayne]3114-the interesting but totally extinguished wayne .[1466-the writer]

" [His]226-lambert name recalls [me]1466-the writer to the details of the scene . The facts were these . A line of red halberdiers , headed by [Wayne]280-wayne , were marching up [the street]394-the street , close under the northern wall , which is , in fact , the bottom of [a sort of dyke or fortification of [the Waterworks]3117-the waterworks]3116-a sort of dyke or fortification of the waterworks . [Lambert]226-lambert and [[his]226-lambert yellow West Kensingtons]3118-his yellow west kensingtons had that instant swept round the corner and had shaken [the Waynites]329-the waynites heavily , hurling back a few of the more timid , as [I]1466-the writer have just described , into [our]3119-our very arms . When [our]3119-our force struck the tail of [Wayne]280-wayne 's , [every one]1959-every one knew that all was up with [him]226-lambert . [[His]226-lambert favourite military barber]3121-his favourite military barber was struck down . [[His]226-lambert grocer]3122-his grocer was stunned . [He]226-lambert [himself]226-lambert was hurt in the thigh , and reeled back against the wall . [We]3119-our had [him]226-lambert in a trap with two jaws . ' Is that [you]3123-you ? ' shouted [Lambert]226-lambert , genially , to [Wilson]328-wilson , across [the hemmed - in host of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill]3124-the hemmed - in host of notting hill . ' That 's about the ticket , ' replied [General Wilson]328-wilson ; ' keep them under the wall . '[1466-the writer]

" [The men of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill]3125-the men of notting hill were falling fast . [Adam Wayne]280-wayne threw up [his]280-wayne long arms to the wall above [him]280-wayne , and with a spring stood upon it ; [a gigantic figure against the moon]3126-a gigantic figure against the moon . [He]280-wayne tore the banner out of the hands of [the standard - bearer below [him]280-wayne]3127-the standard - bearer below him , and shook it out suddenly above [our]3119-our heads , so that it was like thunder in the heavens .[1466-the writer]

" ' Round the Red Lion ! ' [he]280-wayne cried . ' Swords round the Red Lion ! Halberds round [the Red Lion]301-the red lion ! They are the thorns round rose . '[1466-the writer]

" [His]280-wayne voice and the crack of the banner made a momentary rally , and [Lambert]226-lambert , whose idiotic face was almost beautiful with battle , felt it as by an instinct , and cried--[1466-the writer]

" ' Drop [your]226-lambert public - house flag , [[you]226-lambert footler]3128-you footler ! Drop it ! '[1466-the writer]

" ' The banner of the Red Lion seldom stoops , ' said [Wayne]280-wayne , proudly , letting it out luxuriantly on the night wind .[1466-the writer]

" The next moment [I]1466-the writer knew that poor [Adam]280-wayne 's sentimental theatricality had cost [him]280-wayne much . [Lambert]226-lambert was on the wall at a bound , [his]226-lambert sword in [his]226-lambert teeth , and had slashed at [Wayne]280-wayne 's head before [he]226-lambert had time to draw [his]226-lambert sword , [his]226-lambert hands being busy with the enormous flag . [He]226-lambert stepped back only just in time to avoid the first cut , and let the flag - staff fall , so that the spear - blade at the end of it pointed to [Lambert]226-lambert .[1466-the writer]

" ' The banner stoops , ' cried [Wayne]280-wayne , in a voice that must have startled [streets]2779-streets . ' The banner of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill stoops to [a hero]3111-a hero . ' And with the words [he]280-wayne drove the spear - point and half the flag - staff through [Lambert]226-lambert 's body and dropped [him]226-lambert dead upon [the road below]3131-the road below , a stone upon the stones of [the street]394-the street .[1466-the writer]

" ' [Notting Hill]2-notting hill ! [Notting Hill]2-notting hill ! ' cried [Wayne]280-wayne , in a sort of divine rage . ' [Her]2-notting hill banner is all the holier for the blood of [a brave enemy]3133-a brave enemy ! Up on the wall , [patriots]3134-patriots ! Up on the wall ! [Notting Hill]2-notting hill ! '[1466-the writer]

" With [his]280-wayne long strong arm [he]280-wayne actually dragged [a man up on to the wall to be silhouetted against the moon]3135-a man up on to the wall to be silhouetted against the moon , and [more and more men]3136-more and more men climbed up there , pulled [themselves]3136-more and more men and were pulled , till clusters and crowds of [the half - massacred men of [Pump Street]88-pump street]3137-the half - massacred men of pump street massed upon the wall above [us]3138-we .[1466-the writer]

" ' [Notting Hill]2-notting hill ! [Notting Hill]2-notting hill ! ' cried [Wayne]280-wayne , unceasingly .[1466-the writer]

" ' Well , what about [Bayswater]54-bayswater ? ' said [a worthy working - man in [Wilson]328-wilson 's army]3139-a worthy working - man in wilson 's army , irritably . ' [Bayswater]54-bayswater for ever ! '[1466-the writer]

" ' [We]3138-we have won ! ' cried [Wayne]280-wayne , striking [his]280-wayne flag - staff in the ground . ' [Bayswater]54-bayswater for ever ! [We]3138-we have taught [[our]3138-we enemies]3140-our enemies patriotism ! '[1466-the writer]

" ' Oh , cut [these fellows]3141-these fellows up and have done with it ! ' cried [one of [[Lambert]226-lambert 's lieutenants]3143-lambert 's lieutenants , who was reduced to [something bordering on madness by the responsibility of succeeding to the command]3144-something bordering on madness by the responsibility of succeeding to the command]3142-one of lambert 's lieutenants , who was reduced to something bordering on madness by the responsibility of succeeding to the command .[1466-the writer]

" ' Let [us]3138-we by all means try , ' said [Wilson]328-wilson , grimly ; and [the two armies]3145-the two armies closed round the third .[1466-the writer]

* * * * *

" [I]1466-the writer simply can not describe what followed . [I]1466-the writer am sorry , but there is such a thing as physical fatigue , as physical nausea , and , [I]1466-the writer may add , as physical terror . Suffice it to say that the above paragraph was written about 11 p.m. , and that it is now about 2 a.m. , and that the battle is not finished , and is not likely to be . Suffice it further to say that down [the steep streets which lead from [the Waterworks Tower]2958-the waterworks tower to [the Notting Hill High Road]3148-the notting hill high road]3146-the steep streets which lead from the waterworks tower to the notting hill high road , blood has been running , and is running , in great red serpents , that curl out into the main thoroughfare and shine in the moon .[1466-the writer]

* * * * *

" _ Later._--The final touch has been given to all this terrible futility . Hours have passed ; morning has broken ; [men]357-men are still swaying and fighting at the foot of [the tower]3106-the tower and round [the corner of [Aubrey Road]171-aubrey road]3151-the corner of aubrey road ; the fight has not finished . But [I]1466-the writer know it is a farce .[1466-the writer]

" News has just come to show that [Wayne]280-wayne 's amazing sortie , followed by the amazing resistance through a whole night on the wall of [the Waterworks]3117-the waterworks , is as if it had not been . What was the object of that strange exodus [we]3138-we shall probably never know , for the simple reason that [every one who knew will probably be cut to pieces in the course of the next two or three hours]3153-every one who knew will probably be cut to pieces in the course of the next two or three hours .[1466-the writer]

" [I]1466-the writer have heard , about three minutes ago , that [Buck]320-buck and [Buck]320-buck 's methods have won after all . [He]280-wayne was perfectly right , of course , when [one]1758-one comes to think of it , in holding that it was physically impossible for [a street]721-a street to defeat [a city]3156-a city . While [we]3138-we thought [he]280-wayne was patrolling the eastern gates with [[his]280-wayne Purple army]3157-his purple army ; while [we]3138-we were rushing about [the streets]359-the streets and waving halberds and lanterns ; while poor old [Wilson]328-wilson was scheming like [Moltke]330-moltke and fighting like [Achilles]331-achilles to entrap [the wild Provost of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill]3159-the wild provost of notting hill -- [Mr. Buck]273-buck , [retired draper]3160-retired draper , has simply driven down in [a hansom cab]3161-a hansom cab and done something about as plain as butter and about as useful and nasty . [He]273-buck has gone down to [South Kensington]56-south kensington , [Brompton]71-brompton , and [Fulham]62-fulham , and by spending about four thousand pounds of [his]273-buck private means , has raised [an army of nearly as many men]3162-an army of nearly as many men ; that is to say , an army big enough to beat , not only [Wayne]280-wayne , but [Wayne]280-wayne and all [[his]280-wayne present enemies]3163-his present enemies put together . [The army]3086-the army , [I]1466-the writer understand , is encamped along [High Street]85-high street , [Kensington]65-kensington , and fills [it]3086-the army from [the Church]177-the church to [Addison Road Bridge]178-addison road bridge . It is to advance by ten different roads uphill to the north .[1466-the writer]

" [I]1466-the writer can not endure to remain [here]3079-here . Everything makes it worse than it need be . The dawn , for instance , has broken round [Campden Hill]164-campden hill ; splendid spaces of silver , edged with gold , are torn out of the sky . Worse still , [Wayne]280-wayne and [[his]280-wayne men]2793-his men feel the dawn ; [their]2793-his men faces , though bloody and pale , are strangely hopeful ... insupportably pathetic . Worst of all , for the moment [they]2793-his men are winning . If it were not for [Buck]273-buck and [the new army]3167-the new army [they]2793-his men might just , and only just , win .[1466-the writer]

" [I]1466-the writer repeat , [I]1466-the writer can not stand it . It is like watching that wonderful play of old Maeterlinck 's ( [you]3168-you know [my]1466-the writer partiality for [the healthy , jolly old authors of the nineteenth century]3169-the healthy , jolly old authors of the nineteenth century ) , in which [one]1758-one has to watch the quiet conduct of [people]1752-people inside [a parlour]3172-a parlour , while knowing that [the very men are outside the door whose word can blast it all with tragedy]3173-the very men are outside the door whose word can blast it all with tragedy . And this is worse , for [the men]521-the men are not talking , but writhing and bleeding and dropping dead for a thing that is already settled -- and settled against [them]521-the men . The great grey masses of [men]357-men still toil and tug and sway hither and thither around [the great grey tower]3176-the great grey tower ; and [the tower]3106-the tower is still motionless , as it will always be motionless . [These men]2356-these men will be crushed before the sun is set ; and [new men]3179-new men will arise and be crushed , and new wrongs done , and tyranny will always rise again like the sun , and injustice will always be as fresh as the flowers of spring . And [the stone tower]3180-the stone tower will always look down on it . Matter , in [its]3106-the tower brutal beauty , will always look down on [those who are mad enough to consent to die , and yet more mad]3181-those who are mad enough to consent to die , and yet more mad , since [they]3181-those who are mad enough to consent to die , and yet more mad consent to live . "[1466-the writer]

* * * * *

Thus ended abruptly the first and last contribution of [the Special Correspondent of the _ Court Journal]1465-the special correspondent of the _ court journal _ to that valued periodical .

[The Correspondent]1469-the correspondent [himself]1469-the correspondent , as has been said , was simply sick and gloomy at the last news of the triumph of [Buck]273-buck . [He]1469-the correspondent slouched sadly down the steep [Aubrey Road]171-aubrey road , up which [he]1469-the correspondent had the night before run in so unusual an excitement , and strolled out into [the empty dawn - lit main road]1470-the empty dawn - lit main road , looking vaguely for [a cab]1019-a cab . [He]1469-the correspondent saw nothing in [the vacant space]1472-the vacant space except a blue - and - gold glittering thing , running very fast , which looked at first like a very tall beetle , but turned out , to [his]1469-the correspondent great astonishment , to be [Barker]247-barker .

" Have [you]227-auberon heard the good news ? "[1473-that gentleman] asked [that gentleman]1473-that gentleman .

" Yes , "[227-auberon] said [Quin]227-auberon , with a measured voice . " [I]227-auberon have heard the glad tidings of great joy . Shall [we]1474-we take a hansom down to [Kensington]65-kensington ? [I]227-auberon see one over there . "[227-auberon]

[They]1474-we took [the cab]1475-the cab , and were , in four minutes , fronting the ranks of [the multitudinous and invincible army]1476-the multitudinous and invincible army . [Quin]227-auberon had not spoken a word all the way , and something about [him]227-auberon had prevented [the essentially impressionable Barker]247-barker from speaking either .

[The great army]1477-the great army , as it moved up [Kensington High Street]136-kensington high street , calling many heads to the numberless windows , for it was long indeed -- longer than the lives of most of [the tolerably young]1478-the tolerably young -- since such an army had been seen in [London]17-london . Compared with the vast organisation which was now swallowing up the miles , with [Buck]273-buck at [its]1477-the great army head as [leader]1479-leader , and [the King]1924-the king hanging at [its]1477-the great army tail as [journalist]1481-journalist , the whole story of [our]1482-our problem was insignificant . In the presence of [that army]1483-that army the red [Notting Hills]179-notting hills and [the green Bayswaters]150-two hundred green bayswaters were alike [tiny and straggling groups]1484-tiny and straggling groups . In [its]1477-the great army presence the whole struggle round [Pump Street]88-pump street was like [an ant - hill]1485-an ant - hill under the hoof of an ox . [Every man who felt or looked at that infinity of men]1486-every man who felt or looked at that infinity of men knew that it was the triumph of [Buck]273-buck 's brutal arithmetic . Whether [Wayne]280-wayne was right or wrong , wise or foolish , was quite a fair matter for discussion . But it was a matter of history . At the foot of [Church Street]181-church street , opposite [Kensington Church]182-kensington church , [they]1487-they paused in [their]1487-they glowing good humour .

" Let [us]1482-our send some kind of [messenger or herald]3182-messenger or herald up to [them]1487-they , "[273-buck] said [Buck]273-buck , turning to [Barker]247-barker and [the King]1924-the king . " Let [us]1482-our send and ask [them]1487-they to cave in without more muddle . "[273-buck]

" What shall [we]1482-our say to [them]1487-they ? "[247-barker] said [Barker]247-barker , doubtfully .

" The facts of the case are quite sufficient , "[273-buck] rejoined [Buck]273-buck . " It is the facts of the case that make [an army]3183-an army surrender . Let [us]1482-our simply say that [[our]1482-our army that is fighting [[their]1487-they army]1388-their army , and [their]1487-they army that is fighting [[our]1482-our army]3186-our army]3184-our army that is fighting their army , and their army that is fighting our army , amount altogether to about [a thousand men]3187-a thousand men . Say that [we]1482-our have four thousand . It is very simple . Of the thousand fighting , [they]1487-they have at the very most , three hundred , so that , with those three hundred , [they]1487-they have now to fight [four thousand seven hundred men]3188-four thousand seven hundred men . Let [them]1487-they do it if it amuses [them]1487-they . "[273-buck]

And [the Provost of [North Kensington]83-north kensington]856-the provost of north kensington laughed .

[The herald who was despatched up [Church Street]181-church street in all the pomp of the South [Kensington]65-kensington blue and gold , with the Three Birds on [his]1490-the herald who was despatched up church street in all the pomp of the south kensington blue and gold , with the three birds on his tabard tabard]1490-the herald who was despatched up church street in all the pomp of the south kensington blue and gold , with the three birds on his tabard , was attended by [two trumpeters]1491-two trumpeters .

" What will [they]1487-they do when [they]1487-they consent ? "[247-barker] asked [Barker]247-barker , for the sake of saying something in the sudden stillness of [that immense army]1492-that immense army .

" [I]273-buck know [[my]273-buck [Wayne]280-wayne]3189-my wayne very well , "[273-buck] said [Buck]273-buck , laughing . " When [he]280-wayne submits [he]280-wayne will send a red herald flaming with the Lion of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill . Even defeat will be delightful to [him]280-wayne , since it is formal and romantic . "[273-buck]

[The King , who had strolled up to the head of the line]1493-the king , who had strolled up to the head of the line , broke silence for the first time .

" [I]1493-the king , who had strolled up to the head of the line should n't wonder , "[1493-the king , who had strolled up to the head of the line] [he]1493-the king , who had strolled up to the head of the line said , " if [he]280-wayne defied [you]1493-the king , who had strolled up to the head of the line , and did n't send [the herald]861-the herald after all . "[1493-the king , who had strolled up to the head of the line]

" All right , [[your]1493-the king , who had strolled up to the head of the line Majesty]1946-your majesty , "[273-buck] said [Buck]273-buck , easily ; " if it is n't disrespectful , [I]273-buck 'll put [my]273-buck political calculations in a very simple form . [I]273-buck 'll lay [you]1493-the king , who had strolled up to the head of the line ten pounds to a shilling the herald comes with the surrender . "[273-buck]

" All right , "[227-auberon] said [Auberon]227-auberon . " [I]227-auberon may be wrong , but it 's [my]227-auberon notion of [Adam Wayne]280-wayne that [he]280-wayne 'll die in [[his]280-wayne city]3193-his city , and that , till [he]280-wayne is dead , it will not be [a safe property]3194-a safe property . "[227-auberon]

" The bet 's made , [[your]1946-your majesty Majesty]1946-your majesty , "[273-buck] said [Buck]273-buck .

Another long silence ensued , in the course of which [Barker]247-barker alone , amid [the motionless army]1494-the motionless army , strolled and stamped in [his]247-barker restless way .

Then [Buck]273-buck suddenly leant forward .

" [It]3196-it 's taking [your]1946-your majesty money , [[your]1946-your majesty Majesty]1946-your majesty , "[273-buck] [he]273-buck said . " [I]273-buck knew it was . There comes the herald from [Adam Wayne]280-wayne . "[273-buck]

" It 's not , "[1924-the king] cried [the King]1924-the king , peering forward also . " [You]273-buck brute , it 's [a red omnibus]3198-a red omnibus . "[1924-the king]

" It 's not , "[273-buck] said [Buck]273-buck , calmly ; and [the King]1924-the king did not answer , for down [the centre of [the spacious and silent Church Street]1498-the spacious and silent church street]1497-the centre of the spacious and silent church street was walking , beyond question , the herald of the Red Lion , with [two trumpeters]1491-two trumpeters .

[Buck]273-buck had something in [him]273-buck which taught [him]273-buck how to be magnanimous . In [his]273-buck hour of success [he]273-buck felt magnanimous towards [Wayne]280-wayne , whom [he]273-buck really admired ; magnanimous towards [the King]1924-the king , off whom [he]273-buck had scored so publicly ; and , above all , magnanimous towards [Barker]247-barker , who was [the titular leader of [this vast South Kensington army]1502-this vast south kensington army , which [his]247-barker own talent had evoked]1501-the titular leader of this vast south kensington army , which his own talent had evoked .

" [General Barker]332-barker , "[273-buck] [he]273-buck said , bowing , " do [you]332-barker propose now to receive the message from [the besieged]1130-the besieged ? "[273-buck]

[Barker]332-barker bowed also , and advanced towards [the herald]861-the herald .

" Has [[your]332-barker master]3200-your master , [Mr. Adam Wayne]290-wayne , received [our]3201-our request for surrender ? "[273-buck] [he]273-buck asked .

[The herald]861-the herald conveyed a solemn and respectful affirmative .

[Barker]332-barker resumed , coughing slightly , but encouraged .

" What answer does [[your]332-barker master]3200-your master send ? "[332-barker]

[The herald]861-the herald again inclined [himself]861-the herald submissively , and answered in a kind of monotone .

" [My]861-the herald message is this . [Adam Wayne]290-wayne , [Lord High Provost of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill]3203-lord high provost of notting hill , under the charter of [King Auberon]261-auberon and the laws of [God]199-god and all mankind , free and of [a free city]3204-a free city , greets [James Barker]247-barker , [Lord High Provost of [South Kensington]56-south kensington]2122-lord high provost of south kensington , by the same rights free and honourable , [leader of [the army of [the South]112-the south]3207-the army of the south]3206-leader of the army of the south . With all friendly reverence , and with all constitutional consideration , [he]1924-the king desires [James Barker]247-barker to lay down [his]1924-the king arms , and [the whole army under [his]1924-the king command]3208-the whole army under his command to lay down [their]3208-the whole army under his command arms also . "[861-the herald]

Before the words were ended [the King]1924-the king had run forward into the open space with shining eyes . [The rest of [the staff]1508-the staff]1507-the rest of the staff and [the forefront of [the army]3086-the army]1509-the forefront of the army were literally struck breathless . When [they]1507-the rest of the staff recovered [they]1507-the rest of the staff began to laugh beyond restraint ; the revulsion was too sudden .

" [The Lord High Provost of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill]2190-the lord high provost of notting hill , "[861-the herald] continued [the herald]861-the herald , " does not propose , in the event of [your]3210-your surrender , to use [his]2190-the lord high provost of notting hill victory for any of those repressive purposes which [others]1235-others have entertained against [him]2190-the lord high provost of notting hill . [He]2190-the lord high provost of notting hill will leave [you]3210-your [your]3210-your free laws and [[your]3210-your free cities]3212-your free cities , [your]3210-your flags and [[your]3210-your governments]3213-your governments . [He]2190-the lord high provost of notting hill will not destroy the religion of [South Kensington]56-south kensington , or crush the old customs of [Bayswater]54-bayswater . "[861-the herald]

An irrepressible explosion of laughter went up from the forefront of [the great army]1477-the great army .

" [The King]261-auberon must have had something to do with this humour , "[273-buck] said [Buck]273-buck , slapping [his]273-buck thigh . " It 's too deliciously insolent . [Barker]247-barker , have a glass of wine . "[273-buck]

And in [his]273-buck conviviality [he]273-buck actually sent [a soldier]1513-a soldier across to [the restaurant opposite [the church]1771-the church]1514-the restaurant opposite the church and brought out two glasses for a toast .

When the laughter had died down , [the herald]861-the herald continued quite monotonously--

" In the event of [your]247-barker surrendering [your]247-barker arms and dispersing under the superintendence of [[our]3214-our forces]2860-our forces , these local rights of yours shall be carefully observed . In the event of [your]247-barker not doing so , [the Lord High Provost of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill]2190-the lord high provost of notting hill desires to announce that [he]2190-the lord high provost of notting hill has just captured [the Waterworks Tower]2958-the waterworks tower , just above [you]247-barker , on [Campden Hill]164-campden hill , and that within ten minutes from now , that is , on the reception through [me]861-the herald of [your]247-barker refusal , [he]2190-the lord high provost of notting hill will open [the great reservoir]3218-the great reservoir and flood [the whole valley]3219-the whole valley where [you]247-barker stand in thirty feet of water . God save [King Auberon]261-auberon ! "[861-the herald]

[Buck]273-buck had dropped [his]273-buck glass and sent a great splash of wine over [the road]583-the road .

" But -- but-- "[273-buck] [he]273-buck said ; and then by a last and splendid effort of [his]273-buck great sanity , looked the facts in the face .

" [We]3220-we must surrender , "[273-buck] [he]273-buck said . " [You]247-barker could do nothing against fifty thousand tons of water coming down [a steep hill]3221-a steep hill , ten minutes hence . [We]3220-we must surrender . [[Our]3220-we four thousand men]3222-our four thousand men might as well be four . _ Vicisti Galilæe ! _ [Perkins]333-perkins , [you]333-perkins may as well get [me]273-buck another glass of wine . "[273-buck]

In this way [the vast army of [South Kensington]56-south kensington]1518-the vast army of south kensington surrendered and [the Empire of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill]1519-the empire of notting hill began . One further fact in this connection is perhaps worth mentioning -- the fact that , after [his]1520-his victory , [Adam Wayne]290-wayne caused [the great tower on [Campden Hill]164-campden hill]1521-the great tower on campden hill to be plated with gold and inscribed with a great epitaph , saying that it was [the monument of [Wilfrid Lambert]226-lambert]1522-the monument of wilfrid lambert , [the heroic defender of the place]1523-the heroic defender of the place , and surmounted with a statue , in which [his]226-lambert large nose was done something less than justice to .

BOOK V

CHAPTER I--_The Empire of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill _

On the evening of the third of October , twenty years after the great victory of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill , which gave [it]2-notting hill [the dominion of [London]17-london]1524-the dominion of london , [King Auberon]261-auberon came , as of old , out of [Kensington Palace]158-kensington palace .

[He]261-auberon had changed little , save for a streak or two of grey in [his]261-auberon hair , for [his]261-auberon face had always been old , and [his]261-auberon step slow , and , as it were , decrepit .

If [he]261-auberon looked old , it was not because of anything physical or mental . It was because [he]261-auberon still wore , with a quaint conservatism , the frock - coat and high hat of the days before the great war . " [I]261-auberon have survived the Deluge , "[261-auberon] [he]261-auberon said . " [I]261-auberon am [a pyramid]3223-a pyramid , and must behave as such . "[261-auberon]

As [he]261-auberon passed up [the street]394-the street [the Kensingtonians]1526-the kensingtonians , in [their]1526-the kensingtonians picturesque blue smocks , saluted [him]261-auberon as [a King]594-a king , and then looked after [him]261-auberon as a curiosity . It seemed odd to [them]1526-the kensingtonians that [men]357-men had once worn so elvish an attire .

[The King]1924-the king , cultivating the walk attributed to [the oldest inhabitant]1530-the oldest inhabitant ( " [Gaffer Auberon]334-auberon "[1924-the king] [[his]1924-the king friends]639-his friends were now confidentially desired to call [him]1924-the king ) , went toddling northward . [He]1924-the king paused , with reminiscence in [his]1924-the king eye , at [the Southern Gate of [Notting Hill]2-notting hill]1532-the southern gate of notting hill , one of those nine great gates of bronze and steel , wrought with reliefs of the old battles , by the hand of [Chiffy]335-chiffy [himself]335-chiffy .

" Ah ! "[1924-the king] [he]1924-the king said , shaking [his]1924-the king head and assuming an unnecessary air of age , and a provincialism of accent--"Ah ! [I]1924-the king mind when there warn't none of this here . "[1924-the king]

[He]1924-the king passed through [the Ossington Gate]1533-the ossington gate , surmounted by a great lion , wrought in red copper on yellow brass , with the motto , " Nothing Ill. "[1534-the guard in red and gold] [The guard in red and gold]1534-the guard in red and gold saluted [him]1924-the king with [his]1534-the guard in red and gold halberd .

It was about sunset , and the lamps were being lit . [Auberon]334-auberon paused to look at them , for they were [Chiffy]335-chiffy 's finest work , and [his]334-auberon artistic eye never failed to feast on [them]1535-them . In memory of the Great Battle of the Lamps , each great iron lamp was surmounted by a veiled figure , sword in hand , holding over the flame an iron hood or extinguisher , as if ready to let it fall if [the armies of [the South and West]183-the south and west]1536-the armies of the south and west should again show [their]1536-the armies of the south and west flags in [the city]1941-the city . Thus [no child]1538-no child in [Notting Hill]2-notting hill could play about [the streets]359-the streets without the very lamp - posts reminding [him]335-chiffy of the salvation of [[his]335-chiffy country]1073-his country in the dreadful year .

" [Old Wayne]184-old wayne was right in a way , "[1924-the king] commented [the King]1924-the king . " The sword does make things beautiful . It has made [the whole world]2207-the whole world romantic by now . And to think [people]1752-people once thought [me]1924-the king [a buffoon]3226-a buffoon for suggesting a romantic [Notting Hill]2-notting hill . Deary [me]1924-the king , deary [me]1924-the king ! ( [I]1924-the king think that is the expression)--it seems like a previous existence . "[1924-the king]

Turning a corner , [he]1924-the king found [himself]1924-the king in [Pump Street]88-pump street , opposite [the four shops which [Adam Wayne]290-wayne had studied twenty years before]1542-the four shops which adam wayne had studied twenty years before . [He]1924-the king entered idly [the shop of [Mr. Mead]292-mr. mead , [the grocer]2414-the grocer]1543-the shop of mr. mead , the grocer . [Mr. Mead]292-mr. mead was somewhat older , like the rest of [the world]352-the world , and [his]292-mr. mead red beard , which [he]292-mr. mead now wore with a moustache , and long and full , was partly blanched and discoloured . [He]292-mr. mead was dressed in a long and richly embroidered robe of blue , brown , and crimson , interwoven with an Eastern complexity of pattern , and covered with obscure symbols and pictures , representing [his]292-mr. mead wares passing from hand to hand and from [nation]1546-nation to [nation]1546-nation . Round [his]292-mr. mead neck was the chain with the Blue Argosy cut in turquoise , which [he]292-mr. mead wore as [Grand Master of [the Grocers]1549-the grocers]1548-grand master of the grocers . [The whole shop]1550-the whole shop had the sombre and sumptuous look of [its owner]1181-its owner . The wares were displayed as prominently as in the old days , but they were now blended and arranged with a sense of tint and grouping , too often neglected by [the dim grocers of those forgotten days]1552-the dim grocers of those forgotten days . The wares were shown plainly , but shown not so much as [an old grocer]1553-an old grocer would have shown [his]1553-an old grocer stock , but rather as [an educated virtuoso]1554-an educated virtuoso would have shown [his]1553-an old grocer treasures . The tea was stored in great blue and green vases , inscribed with the nine indispensable sayings of [the wise men of [China]106-china]1555-the wise men of china . Other vases of a confused orange and purple , less rigid and dominant , more humble and dreamy , stored symbolically the tea of [India]105-india . A row of caskets of a simple silvery metal contained tinned meats . Each was wrought with some rude but rhythmic form , as a shell , a horn , a fish , or an apple , to indicate what material had been canned in it .

" [[Your]3227-your Majesty]1946-your majesty , "[292-mr. mead] said [Mr. Mead]292-mr. mead , sweeping an Oriental reverence . " This is an honour to [me]292-mr. mead , but yet more an honour to [the city]1941-the city . "[292-mr. mead]

[Auberon]334-auberon took off [his]334-auberon hat .

" [Mr. Mead]292-mr. mead , "[292-mr. mead] [he]292-mr. mead said , " [Notting Hill]2-notting hill , whether in giving or taking , can deal in nothing but honour . Do [you]292-mr. mead happen to sell liquorice ? "[292-mr. mead]

" Liquorice , [sire]2202-sire , "[292-mr. mead] said [Mr. Mead]292-mr. mead , " is not the least important of [our]3231-our benefits out of [the dark heart of [Arabia]185-arabia]3232-the dark heart of arabia . "[292-mr. mead]

And going reverently towards a green and silver canister , made in the form of [an Arabian mosque]1556-an arabian mosque , [he]292-mr. mead proceeded to serve [[his]292-mr. mead customer]1557-his customer .

" [I]1924-the king was just thinking , [Mr. Mead]292-mr. mead , "[1924-the king] said [the King]1924-the king , reflectively , " [I]1924-the king do n't know why [I]1924-the king should think about it just now , but [I]1924-the king was just thinking of twenty years ago . Do [you]292-mr. mead remember the times before the war ? "[1924-the king]

[The grocer]2414-the grocer , having wrapped up the liquorice sticks in a piece of paper ( inscribed with some appropriate sentiment ) , lifted [his]2414-the grocer large grey eyes dreamily , and looked at the darkening sky outside .

" Oh yes , [[your]1924-the king Majesty]1946-your majesty , "[2414-the grocer] [he]2414-the grocer said . " [I]2414-the grocer remember [these streets]2334-these streets before [the Lord Provost]3235-the lord provost began to rule [us]3236-we . [I]2414-the grocer ca n't remember how [we]3236-we felt very well . All the great songs and the fighting change one so ; and [I]2414-the grocer do n't think [we]3236-we can really estimate all [we]3236-we owe to [the Provost]280-wayne ; but [I]2414-the grocer can remember [his]280-wayne coming into [this very shop]3237-this very shop twenty - two years ago , and [I]2414-the grocer remember the things [he]280-wayne said . The singular thing is that , as far as [I]2414-the grocer remember , [I]2414-the grocer thought the things [he]280-wayne said odd at that time . Now it 's the things that [I]2414-the grocer said , as far as [I]2414-the grocer can recall them , that seem to [me]2414-the grocer odd -- as odd as [a madman]591-a madman 's antics . "[2414-the grocer]

" Ah ! "[1924-the king] said [the King]1924-the king ; and looked at [him]1924-the king with an unfathomable quietness .

" [I]1924-the king thought nothing of being [a grocer]1110-a grocer then , "[1924-the king] [he]1924-the king said . " Is n't that odd enough for [anybody]1971-anybody ? [I]1924-the king thought nothing of all the wonderful places that [my]1924-the king goods come from , and wonderful ways that they are made . [I]1924-the king did not know that [I]1924-the king was for all practical purposes [a king with [slaves]2312-slaves spearing fishes near [the secret pool]3243-the secret pool]3241-a king with slaves spearing fishes near the secret pool , and gathering fruits in [the islands under the world]3244-the islands under the world . [My]1924-the king mind was a blank on the thing . [I]1924-the king was as mad as [a hatter]2681-a hatter . "[1924-the king]

[The King]1924-the king turned also , and stared out into the dark , where the great lamps that commemorated the battle were already flaming .

" And is this the end of poor old [Wayne]280-wayne ? "[1924-the king] [he]1924-the king said , half to [himself]1924-the king . " To inflame [every one]1959-every one so much that [he]280-wayne is lost [himself]280-wayne in the blaze . Is this [his]280-wayne victory that [he]280-wayne , [[my]1924-the king incomparable Wayne]3247-my incomparable wayne , is now only one in [a world of [Waynes]186-waynes]3248-a world of waynes ? Has [he]280-wayne conquered and become by conquest commonplace ? Must [Mr. Mead]292-mr. mead , [the grocer]2414-the grocer , talk as high as [he]280-wayne ? [Lord]2297-lord ! what a strange world in which [a man]388-a man can not remain unique even by taking the trouble to go mad ! "[1924-the king]

And [he]1924-the king went dreamily out of [the shop]1140-the shop .

[He]1924-the king paused outside [the next one]1563-the next one almost precisely as [the Provost]876-the provost had done two decades before .

[ Illustration : " A FINE EVENING , [SIR]1754-sir , "[1129-the chemist] SAID [THE CHEMIST]1129-the chemist . ]

" How uncommonly creepy [this shop]3253-this shop looks ! "[1129-the chemist] [he]1129-the chemist said . " But yet somehow encouragingly creepy , invitingly creepy . It looks like something in a jolly old nursery story in which [you]3254-you are frightened out of [your]3254-you skin , and yet know that things always end well . The way those low sharp gables are carved like great black bat 's wings folded down , and the way those queer - coloured bowls underneath are made to shine like giants eye - balls . It looks like [[a benevolent warlock]3255-a benevolent warlock 's hut]3256-a benevolent warlock 's hut . It is apparently [a chemist]1111-a chemist 's . "[1129-the chemist]

Almost as [he]1129-the chemist spoke , [Mr. Bowles]296-mr. bowles , [the chemist]1129-the chemist , came to [[his]1129-the chemist shop]1170-his shop door in a long black velvet gown and hood , monastic as it were , but yet with a touch of the diabolic . [His]1129-the chemist hair was still quite black , and [his]1129-the chemist face even paler than of old . The only spot of colour [he]1129-the chemist carried was a red star cut in some precious stone of strong tint , hung on [his]1129-the chemist breast . [He]1129-the chemist belonged to [the Society of the Red Star of Charity]1568-the society of the red star of charity , founded on the lamps displayed by [doctors]1569-doctors and [chemists]2463-chemists .

" A fine evening , [sir]1754-sir , "[1129-the chemist] said [the chemist]1129-the chemist . " Why , [I]1129-the chemist can scarcely be mistaken in supposing it to be [[your]1754-sir Majesty]1946-your majesty . Pray step inside and share a bottle of sal - volatile , or anything that may take [your]1754-sir fancy . As it happens , there is an old acquaintance of [[your]1754-sir Majesty]1946-your majesty 's in [[my]1129-the chemist shop]3261-my shop carousing ( if [I]1129-the chemist may be permitted the term ) upon that beverage at this moment . "[1129-the chemist]

[The King]1924-the king entered [the shop]1140-the shop , which was [an Aladdin 's garden of shades and hues]1574-an aladdin 's garden of shades and hues , for as [the chemist]1129-the chemist 's scheme of colour was more brilliant than [the grocer]2414-the grocer 's scheme , so it was arranged with even more delicacy and fancy . Never , if the phrase may be employed , had such a nosegay of medicines been presented to the artistic eye .

But even the solemn rainbow of that evening interior was rivalled or even eclipsed by [the figure standing in the centre of [the shop]1140-the shop]1577-the figure standing in the centre of the shop . [His]1577-the figure standing in the centre of the shop form , which was a large and stately one , was clad in a brilliant blue velvet , cut in the richest Renaissance fashion , and slashed so as to show gleams and gaps of a wonderful lemon or pale yellow . [He]1577-the figure standing in the centre of the shop had several chains round [his]1577-the figure standing in the centre of the shop neck , and [his]1577-the figure standing in the centre of the shop plumes , which were of several tints of bronze and gold , hung down to the great gold hilt of [his]1577-the figure standing in the centre of the shop long sword . [He]1577-the figure standing in the centre of the shop was drinking a dose of sal - volatile , and admiring its opal tint . [The King]1924-the king advanced with a slight mystification towards the tall figure , whose face was in shadow ; then [he]1924-the king said--

" By [the Great Lord of Luck]3262-the great lord of luck , [Barker]247-barker ! "[1924-the king]

[The figure]1580-the figure removed [his]1580-the figure plumed cap , showing the same dark head and long , almost equine face which [the King]1924-the king had so often seen rising out of the high collar of [Bond Street]187-bond street . Except for a grey patch on [each temple]1582-each temple , it was totally unchanged .

" [[Your]1924-the king Majesty]1946-your majesty , "[247-barker] said [Barker]247-barker , " this is a meeting nobly retrospective , a meeting that has about it a certain October gold . [I]1924-the king drink to old days ; "[1924-the king] and [he]1924-the king finished [his]1924-the king sal - volatile with simple feeling .

" [I]1924-the king am delighted to see [you]247-barker again , [Barker]247-barker , "[1924-the king] said [the King]1924-the king . " It is indeed long since [we]3264-we met . What with [my]1924-the king travels in [Asia Minor]188-asia minor , and [my]1924-the king book having to be written ( [you]247-barker have read [my]1924-the king ' Life of [Prince Albert]336-prince albert for [Children]367-children , ' of course ? ) , [we]3264-we have scarcely met twice since the Great War . That is twenty years ago . "[1924-the king]

" [I]247-barker wonder , "[247-barker] said [Barker]247-barker , thoughtfully , " if [I]247-barker might speak freely to [[your]247-barker Majesty]1946-your majesty ? "[247-barker]

" Well , "[334-auberon] said [Auberon]334-auberon , " it 's rather late in the day to start speaking respectfully . Flap away , [my]334-auberon bird of freedom . "[334-auberon]

" Well , [[your]247-barker Majesty]1946-your majesty , "[247-barker] replied [Barker]247-barker , lowering [his]247-barker voice , " [I]247-barker do n't think it will be so long to the next war . "[247-barker]

" What do [you]247-barker mean ? "[334-auberon] asked [Auberon]334-auberon .

" [We]3264-we will stand this insolence no longer , "[247-barker] burst out [Barker]247-barker , fiercely . " [We]3264-we are not [slaves]2312-slaves because [Adam Wayne]280-wayne twenty years ago cheated [us]3264-we with a water - pipe . [Notting Hill]2-notting hill is [Notting Hill]2-notting hill ; it is not [the world]352-the world . [We]3264-we in [South Kensington]56-south kensington , [we]3264-we also have memories -- ay , and hopes .
